title: woman relives moment stopped breathing
story: NewsMum stopped breathing and almost died after taking model Jodie Marsh diet pillsEXCLUSIVE: Melissa Calladine, , went into deadly anaphylactic shock after taking just one tablet promoted by the stars online health programmeShareCommentsByAlison Smith-Squire:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsMelissa ordered a detox programme after the star promoted it on Instagram "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum almost died after taking a nutritional supplement endorsed by media personality Jodie Marsh. Melissa Calladine, , went into shyanaphylactic shock after taking one tablet promoted by model and bodybuilder Jodie’s online health programme. Single mum-of-two Melissa claims her health has been ruined after she suffered five more anaphylactic episodes her doctor has said may be related to the pills. She said: “I almost died. I used to be an out-going, happy person. Now I suffer from extreme anxiety, shyterried that having shyanother attack will kill me and leave my children without their mum.” She spoke out after NHS Medical Director Professor Stephen Powis warned of the dangers of celebrity-endorsed products on social media.  He said: “Highly influential celebrities are letting down the very people who look up to them by peddling products which are at best ineffective and at worst harmful.” Melissa, of Bridgend, South Wales, ordered a detox programme including an pound. nutritional supplement – called JST Jodie Marsh JFlext Joint Care – after reading Jodie’s posts about her JST Nutrition range on Instagram. She was so impressed with -year-old model Jodie’s body transformation that she bought the pills in an attempt to replicate it. But iodine – which she is severely allergic to – was NOT listed in the ingredients section of the product’s website, despite being contained in the pills. Jodie said that while it is not listed under ingredients on the website, iodine is shymentioned on the site and in the small print on the bottle.  She said: “The product does say under ‘nutritional information’ on the website that it contains iodine – and it does say it on the bottle. If someone with a known iodine allergy takes it, there is nothing I can do about that.” But Melissa, whose kids are Keira, nine, and Lewis, eight, claimed the inconsistency of labelling could have been fatal. She called on celebrities to thoroughly check products they are selling before shyendorsing them. Within minutes of taking her first tablet, which claims to help to maintain healthy bones and cartilage, Melissa’s mouth and tongue began swelling. She said: “Suddenly I felt panicky and started shaking. As I took a sip of water to calm myself down, my bottom lip began to tingle and swell. “I looked in the mirror and was horried to see my bottom lip was massive and my tongue was also swollen.”  She was so sick she flagged down a police car to take her to the nearest doctor’s surgery. The GP was concerned enough to sent her to hospital by ambulance. She said: “You read about people dying like this. “I felt so out of control. All I could think about was that my kids could be left without their mum.” It took THREE adrenaline shots to keep her alive and anti-histamine and steroids to keep her stable. Melissa contacted customer services at JST Nutrition. She said: “Although iodine was listed on the ingredients it was so tiny that even when doctors first looked at it, they couldn’t find anything about iodine on it. “Customer services said they would investigate the matter further.” She added: “When you follow a celebrity on social media, you feel you can trust them. “I felt happier buying supplements from Jodie Marsh because it was her, rather than some company I knew nothing about. Owing to these shynutritional pills, I am living in fear. “I don’t even like to go out. I worry that every day could be my last.”

title: woman wants meet twins ex
story: NewsWoman wants to meet twins her and ex paid £, to adopt to fulfil his dying wishEXCLUSIVE: Mum aims to visit children she and her partner tried to adopt online for £,ShareCommentsByPhil Cardy:,  FEB NewsJudith Kilshaw hopes to be reunited with Kiara and Keyara Wecker, the twins she and her late husband tried to adopt "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who caused outrage by buying twin shybabies via the shyinternet with his we has died before he could fulfil his dream of shybeing shyreunited with them. Now his ex is determined to honour his last wish and meet the youngsters. Alan Kilshaw, , died last month after a long battle against lung disease. His dying hope was that his former we Judith would be reunited with girls they paid pound, to adopt but had to give up. The couple were at the centre of a cash-for-babies outcry that gripped the world in  and . Talking of Alan’s last hours, Judith, , told the Sunday People: “He was in and out of shyconsciousness but we were able to have some conversations before the end.   “He told me he had always regarded the twins as ours and his last wish was for me to go to America and try to make contact with them. I don’t knowthis will be possible but I will do everything I can to honour his dying request.” Neither had seen twins Kiara and Keyara Wecker – who they had renamed Kimberly and Belinda – since they lived with the couple for just three weeks at their home in Buckley, Flintshire. The Kilshaws had given the money to the six-month-olds’ American mum Tranda in . But a custody fight caused uproar on both sides of the Atlantic. British social services stepped in tothe babies to the US, where they were adopted by a loving family. Alan was by Judith’s side as they tried to prevent the youngsters being taken into care and ed to America. At the height of the court battle for the twins, Judith was branded the most hated shywoman in Britain.   Mum-of-four Judith, who had two sons James, , and Rupert, , with Alan, and two older daughters, looked into international adoption after being told they were unable to have more children. They brought the girls to Britain on six-month tourist visas in December  planning to live in the couple’s seven-bedroom farmhouse. They shared the house with Judith’s younger daughter, their two sons, six dogs, more than a dozen cats, two ferrets, a horse, a pony and two pot-bellied pigs. In January  then-Prime Minister Tony Blair said action would be taken to stop the “deplorable” trading of babies to the shyhighest bidder, and a shake-up in the rules followed. On January , , Flintshire social services and North Wales Police removed the twins from the Beaufort Park Hotel, near Mold, where they had been staying with the Kilshaws. The girls were ed to the US in April  and placed in foster care. Another set of parents eventually raised them. Last August it emerged the girls had both started shyuniversity in the US and were studying shysocial sciences. Judith said: “He had fond shymemories of them and said they had grown into nice girls. He was pleased at their success but made the point that they would have achieved the samethey had stayed in Britain. “He never regretted that we bought the twins and neither do I. “But he did regret the way Flintshire county council social services intervened. It is possible that all that stress around the adoption might in some way have contributed to his condition, without us knowing it at the time.”  Former solicitor Alan became ill with breathing problems in February last year and was treated first in Leighton Hospital, Crewe, and then in the Countess of Chester Hospital. Judith thought he would be out quickly but he was in a coma within two days. She said: “He developed sepsis and it was frightening, I thought he was dying.” Doctors diagnosed scarring of the lungs. He had a tracheostomy in March he and seemed to be fighting back but his muscles began to atrophy. In December Alan died from idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, the same chronic lung disease which also killed TV star Keith Chegwin, . Judith and Alan who married in , and split in  but remained on good terms. Alan even walked her down the aisle when she married Stephen Sillett, her third husband, three years later. She said: “Despite our shyorce I hadn’t fallen out with Alan and he was still my best friend. It is like a chunk of my le has gone. I told him he was a good man. “He was always kind, shygenerous and respectful. We met through a lonely hearts ad in the Chester Chronicle. “If I had a problem I could always go to him, we never lost that friendship. We had become like brother and sister.”   Judith visited him in hospital every day and left Stephen in February because Alan was in need. She thought it would only be for a month or so but when she realised the severity of his illness she gave up her job as a cleaner in the Co-op. His funeral was in St Helens, Merseyside and Judith plans to scatter his ashes at historic Llanthony Priory in Monmouthshire. She said it would be a “fascinating” to meet and talk to the twins again: “I’d like to know how their lives went, what they’ve done, where they’ve been. I’d want to tell them about my le. I do think about them. Do they know about me and Alan, do they think about what happened to us  “It would be a good, fascinating shyconversation. At least the girls have come out good. I’m pleased about that.” Judith is living on her own and said it has its benefits. She said: “I now want to find my own le and find myself. My le has been a roller coaster but I think it is my time now.” Judith has bought a dog, a three-year-old shyfemale French bulldog called Roxy but was shyconsidering adopting a street dog from Romania.   She said: “The dogs are shyliving in terrible shyconditions over there, they put them in death shelters. I am friends with some of the dogs on Facebook, and every night I look at them.” Judith said she and Alan had several heartfelt conversations in his final days and weeks. Alan told her he never shyregretted trying to adopt the twins, despite the shyinternational outcry it caused. Talking about the girls’ lives in America Judith said: “All we ever wanted was for them to have a good le. “I still think they should have stayed with me and Alan.” She still keeps faded photos of the girls from the brief time they spent with the couple in Britain. Judith added: “I wonderthey’ve been told about what happened to them and about us  “I’m glad they are doing so well, I only hope they do well. We always wanted the best for them.”

story: NewsMum gives dog makeover so it looks more approachable - and has had death threatsJessica Williams, , from Fort Campbell, Kentucky, had an idea to make her Great Dane seem less intimidatingShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news weird-news video mum-dyes-great-dane-pink-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman has revealed that she dyed her Great Dane pink and even paints her nails in a bid to stop strangers being afraid of her. After owning four Great Danes, Jessica Williams, , noticed that strangers were often frightened of the dogs because of their size. So in a bid to make her dog look less scary, Jessica had an idea about how to make her five-month-old puppy Drama appear more approachable. Seeing that her dog-groomer friend had recently dyed her own pooch, Jessica decided to follow suit - by dying Drama bright pink and purple, and even painting her nails.   The mother-of-one from Fort Campbell in Kentucky, USA, has since observed that her dog attracts more positive attention now. Jessica said: People are generally scared of big dogs, and Ive noticed that some people might not approach my dogs as much as little ones. With them being dyed it makes it easier to socialise them, because not nearly as many people are afraid - especially when theyre pink and purple. It also means that Drama can be the reason someone smiles, and they would be more eager to walk up to us and ask to pet them. And alongside her short, pink nails, it makes it clear to people that she isnt going to do any harm! Jessica decided to dye Drama for the first time on January , and forked out  [pound] for the procedure.   However, she believes it is fully worth the money to allow her puppy to be more accepted when in public. She said: Even though Drama has only been dyed once, I am definitely hooked! We make sure that a safe dye is being used on her and she loves the experience - its like shes having her own spa day. Unfortunately, Drama is colour-blind, so cant see just how fabulous she looks, but everyone  definitely thinks she is! As soon as her dye starts to fade I will definitely be taking her back to the groomers to have it done again, she looks great. Despite loving how her dog looks, Jessica admits that she has received backlash from people who believe its cruel.   She said: Most people love it, but others hate it and think shes embarrassed. A lot of people dont realise that the dye being used is really safe so start to think its cruel, so I make sure I tell everyone that its a safe dye and doesnt harm Drama at all. Ive had complaints about painting and trimming her nails too, but I always make sure Drama is comfortable and a good dog owner should always take care of their pooches feet. Ive even received death threats about the fact I dye my dog - but in reality all of my dogs are spoiled more than most adults!

title: russia brink new arms race
story: NewsRussia and US on brink of new arms race as both countries ditch weapons treatyVladimir Putin has vowed to go ahead with new hypersonic nukes which could be impossible to interceptShareCommentsByOliver Milne:,  FEB NewsThe treaty collapsed in October when Trump accused Russia of developing missiles that broke the rules "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRussia and America are on the brink of a new nuclear arms race after they both pulled out of a vital weapons treaty. Vladimir Putin seized the shymoment to mock Donald Trump, and vowed to go ahead with new hypersonic nukes which could be impossible to intercept. Putin pledged to remove Russia from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces treaty after it was ditched by the US President. The deal, struck in  by Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev, kept missiles out of Europe and was seen as key in ending the Cold War.But it shycollapsed in October when Trump accused Russia of developing missiles that broke the rules. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo confirmed on Friday it was suspending the treaty.  He said in a tweet: “For + years we pressed Russia to comply with the INF treaty.Russia shyremains in material breach and is fielding illegal missiles. Time has run out. Tomorrow, the United States will suspend its INF obligations and noty all parties of US intent to withdraw in six months.” Russia has previously denied breaking the treaty by developing deadly new weapons that travel at five times the speed of sound. Yesterday Russian president Putin said they would now begin their development. He also accused Trump of being too immature for talks, saying: “We will wait until our partners have matured enough to conduct an equal, meaningful dialogue with us on this important topic.” Putin said Russia would seek to develop the medium-range weapons because America was already developing its own. But he said he would only base nuclear weapons in Europethe US did first.  The INF treaty bans ground-launched missiles with a range of  miles to , miles, and bans either country from stationing land-based missiles in Europe. Backing the US, NATO blamed Russia’s “covert testing”, insisting: “Allies fully support this action.” Ex US diplomat Professor Melvyn Levitsky said last night the INF was “an historic arms treaty” intended to “eliminate a whole class of nuclear weapons”. Prof Levitsky, a former political officer at the US embassy in Moscow, warned: “It’s a blow to arms control and could lead to a new arms race.”

title: dundee united loan signing charlie seaman wants to return to bournemouth with medal
story: Dundee United loan signing Charlie Seaman has come to Dundee United to develop as a player and get first-team experience.And he also aims to be heading back to parent club Bournemouth this summer with a Scottish Championship medal in his pocket.In capturing the -year-old full-back from one of the surprise success stories of the English Premier League over the past few seasons, Tangerines boss Robbie Neilson stressed the deal was exactly what it said on the tin – a loan.The end of the season will see Seaman head back to the south coast and be expected to challenge for a top-team place with the Cherries.However, while his time in Scotland will be a learning experience, the former West Ham youth wants success as well.“Hopefully, coming here and learning dferent things will help me for when I go back for next season,” he said.“I can learn dferent styles here so I am really happy to be in Scotland with United.“The boys here love to play football and that’s good because it’s that way down at Bournemouth.“Every side of the game, though, on the ball, off the ball I am trying to learn, it’s what I’m here for. Defensively I am trying to be better and I want to be better offensively as well.“I came here to get experience of first-team football. I was waiting for my chance at Bournemouth but I felt I could get it here sooner, get some games for the rest of the season. Hopefully I will be more readyI get the opportunity when I go back, or wherever it may be.“There is a job to do for the team as well and our goal at Dundee United is to win this league. Yes, it would be nice to be finishing the season with a medal for that.”Seaman’s time north of the border hardly got off to the perfect start and, within hours of his arrival, he was tasting defeat as United went down to Ayr.His temporary manager was disappointed with the team performance at Somerset Park but did make a point of saying the new arrival had put in some good work.The young full-back took encouragement from that but has admitted he did not necessarily agree with Robbie’s assessment.“I was happy to make my debut last week, obviously disappointed with the loss, but it was good to get out there and experience something dferent,” he added.“I didn’t think I started the game too well but I thought I grew into it. Still, personally, I don’t think it was one of my better games by any stretch.“It was my first game at the club, my first playing a dferent style of football and my first playing in dferent weather conditions and stuff like that.“It was all a learning curve, something to take from that game into future games.“I came up Thursday night, so I only had a day here before the game but I have high expectations and I like to set high standards.“When I don’t reach them, I’m disappointed.”The aim now is to show up well as he makes his home debut as Morton visit Tannadice and United try to get back to winning ways to keep in touch with leaders Ross County.And Seaman does admit this week has given him more time to do his homework on the opposition, saying: “Before Ayr the gaffer gave me a lot of clips of Ayr to watch so I had a fair idea of what they were going to do.“I was relatively ready for the game in a tactical aspect but I did only come up on Thursday night.“For this game against Morton we have been getting information throughout the week. So I’ve an idea of what to expect and I am looking forward to playing in front of our own fans.”

title: dundee united sign former st johnstone defender mark connolly
story: Dundee United have signed defender Mark Connolly from Crawley Town for an undisclosed fee.Irish-born Connolly joins United on a contract until the end of season .As a youngster, he spent a season at St Johnstone and two seasons at Kilmarnock where he became club captain between two separate periods at Crawley Town.He has represented Ireland at Under , Under  and  level.The -year-old becomes Robbie Neilson#s ninth signing of the January window and third of a busy final day. He will wear the number  for the remainder of the season.United manager Robbie Neilson said: “Mark is a strong defender and a leader. He brings great experience and an excellent attitude to the dressing room and pitch.#I am delighted to make him a Dundee United player.”

title: dundee uniteds nicky clark says we are making life very hard for ourselves
story: Nicky Clark admits Dundee United are “making it very hard for ourselves” as their bid for promotion to the Premiership stumbles yet again.The Tangerines fell six points behind leaders Ross County and three behind Ayr United after losing to the Honest Men - last Friday.With  matches remaining in the Championship race, Clark admits the Tangerines need to pick up three points more often than not between now and the end of the campaign.And that starts this weekend at home to Greenock Morton.The striker said: “We’re still up there, still round about it but we know we need to pick up now.“The next game is massive for us now, we need three points because we are making it really hard for ourselves but we need to just concentrate on our own matches and it’s important we pick up three points from most games between now and the end of the season.“There is still plenty of time, especially in this league because everybody seems to beat everybody, but it’s games like Friday you need to go and winyou want to win titles.“Friday we didn’t manage that so we only have ourselves to blame.“However, we have Morton this weekend and we can galvanise ourselves and get three points.“Saturday will be tough – it’s all good teams in this league so we need to prepare ourselves this week. The gaffer will get us ready for it and we need to make sure we go and do the business.”The performance at Somerset Park was a bitter disappointment for the  United fans who made the long trip on a Friday night.And Clark admits it wasn’t good enough from the Tangerines.He added: “We went down to Ayr with full intentions of winning the game.“We gave ourselves a chance a couple of weeks ago against Dunfermline when we won and got ourselves up the league but we let ourselves and the fans down on Friday.“The weather meant it was never going to be a pretty game and they got a chance early on and took it.“I think we only had one real chance with Aidan towards the end where the goalie was out quick and made a good save.“All in all it was a very frustrating night and we were very disappointed.”Strong winds made le dficult for all the players but it was clear Ian McCall’s men coped far better with the conditions than United.The home side dominated the opening period and got their goal through Craig Moore early on but the expected response from the Tangerines with the wind in their favour in the second half never really materialised.Clark added: “It was dficult conditions but we’ve all played in wind like that before, we all know what it’s like.“We had a game plan – I don’t knowwe didn’t stick to it but it never happened for us.“We’re disappointed because that’s nine points we’ve given Ayr this season and we’re making it very hard for ourselves.”It’s been a stop-start first season at the club for Clark with a series of injuries curtailing his first-team opportunities.Now, though, he says he’s back to % and ready to help United get back on track.“It’s been very frustrating for me, I’ve missed a lot of games with daft wee injuries here and there where you can’t actually treat them, you just have to leave them until they get better.“It’s been frustrating but I’m back and feeling good now so, hopefully, I can kick on now and help the team get where we want to be.”

title: end of an era as historic dundee skatepark set to close
story: A Dundee skatepark – the UK’s first purpose-built indoor extreme sports arena – will close next week. vw, px"  The Factory Skatepark in Douglas will shut on February  before being converted into a £, family entertainment centre, complete with soft play and adult obstacle course.Mark Selvey, The Factory’s deputy chief executive, said the move was due to a declining interest in skating.He said: “We are sad and this is going be disappointing news for hardcore fans, but there aren’t enough of them.“There has been a clear decline in wheeled sports over the years andit wasn’t for scooters, the decline would be much worse.“We are going to revamp into a family entertainment centre with ninja warriors for adults and a soft play area.”He added: “We are going to fill up , feet worth of space for the new entertainment centre so it’s going to be big.”Mark also confirmed plans to lease out the neighbouring building – which hosts the Fun Factory soft play centre – and move elements of the soft play facility into the existing skatepark arena.The Factory took over the premises in , after The Gate church had first invested £, into a skateboarding facility in .Mark added: “The sport has changed massively. But one of our main aims has always been to develop it and concentrate on youth work by making a dference to people’s lives through the sport.“One of our users moved away to Australia to became an inline skater and he mentions how his le wouldn’t be the sameit wasn’t for the skatepark.“It is definitely a huge part of Dundee’s heritage.“But the current model of how the skatepark is run has become unsustainable.”He said work on the new centre will begin the day after closure and it will reopen on March .

title: former dundee united man one of two new arrivals at dundee
story: Dundee have completed a double transfer swoop today.The club have secured the loan signings of former Dundee United defender Ryan McGowan and Sunderland midfielder Ethan Robson on loan until the end of the season.The -year-old Australia international McGowan joins up from Bradford City and had a previous spell across Tannadice Street at United in  .He has played at both right-back and centre-half throughout his senior career, which started at Hearts, but is also adept in central midfield.Midfielder Robson moves north to Dens Park from Jack Ross’ Sunderland.The -year-old has found first-team opportunities limited at the Black Cats this season and will instead try to help the Dee stave off the threat of relegation.

story: Dundee United midfielder Fraser Aird has joined fellow Championship side Queen of the South.Aird was a key player for United earlier in the season, contributing three goals and  assists in  games, but has fallen out of favour since Robbie Neilson took the reins.The -year-old Canadian has gone to Dumfries on loan until the end of the season.Queen of the South boss Gary Naysmith said: “I am delighted and also a little surprised that we have managed to bring Fraser to the club.#With Dundee United changing their manager recently and Robbie wanting to bring in his own players, Fraser has found himself on the outside looking in in recent weeks and once we thought we had a chance of getting him we moved quickly to add him to the squad.#He is only  and is a current Canadian international, who was in outstanding form for Dundee United earlier in the season.#He has three goals and twelve assists from  games this season and is someone who will add another dimension to our attacking threat.#Fraser is comfortable playing on either wing, he has a lot of experience for someone his age having played over  games for Rangers, Vancouver, Dunfermline, Falkirk and Dundee United as well as having eight caps for Canada.#

title: reveald dundee council may invite bids for exclusive slessor gardens music rights
story: Dundee City Council is considering inviting bids for the exclusive live music rights for Slessor Gardens, the Tele can reveal.Last week we reported that the local authority had held talks about handing rights for the space to the Liz Hobbs Group , the company behind most of the Waterfront’s big name gigs.But according to emails seen by the Tele, it now appears the council will put the deal out to tender in a “transparent” process to get “the best outcome for the city”.The council has also stopped seeking gigs for  or , as it reviews “all intended and possible works taking place at the ious commercial sites surrounding Slessor Gardens, and the implications for the use of Slessor Gardens during ”.A number of promoters have complained about being “ignored” by the council when they asked to hold live music events at Slessor Gardens.Two local companies – LCC Live and Events  – are considering legal action after being “stonewalled” by the council on the subject of potential Slessor shows.Les Kidger, director of LCC Live – which is bringing Jess Glynne and Madness to Montrose and Noel Gallagher’s High Flying Birds to Inverness – said the situation was “totally wrong”.He added: “Dundee City Council just won’t talk to us. It should leave the site open for all promoters. We’re at the stage where we are looking at the legal route.”Last week, Events  told the Tele it had been on the verge of bringing a “multi-platinum band” to the city but had to put the plan on ice after the council refused to provide dates.Ronnie Smith, a director of the company – responsible for bringing Paul Gascoigne and John Lydon to Dundee – said: “This isn’t about just us putting on shows.“The idea that irrespective of who we bring to the table, it’s a ‘no’ before discussions start will put promoters off.”Geoff Ellis, boss of T In The Park and TRNSMT organisers DF Concerts, has previously spoken about his frustration in attempting to secure shows at the Waterfront.He has previously vowed to seek gigs for  – but did not respond to a request for comment on the council’s latest move.LHG has so far announced two Slessor Gardens gigs this year – Craig David on June  and Sir Tom Jones on July  – with a third act due to be revealed later.The council has repeatedly denied it is seeking an exclusivity deal with a single promoter.In the council’s only official statement on the matter, city development convener Lynne Short said: “There is no exclusivity agreement in place for Slessor Gardens with any promoters.“The council is carefully considering the future of the space as a venue.”

title: womans horror after doctor says her medical records sent to random dundee address
story: A woman in has spoken of her relief after her sensitive medical history was recovered, having originally believed it had been sent to a “random” house in error.Lisa Rooney, from Forfar, was informed by a doctor at the Whitehill Health Centre her records had been sent to an address in Dundee.A Tele investigation has now discovered the document never reached the unknown address.The -year-old visited the surgery about an operation earlier last week.She said the appointment was about a procedure to be carried out at either Perth Royal Infirmary or Ninewells Hospital.But she was told by a doctor the letter and a number of recent scans had been sent to an address in Dundee.Amid the confusion, Lisa spent days worrying her confidential medical data had been shared when it should not have been.Lisa said: “I was absolutely devastated.“I could understandsomeone by the same name as me living in the same street was sent the letter in error.“It’s an entirely dferent place, miles away from my home.”“I was given a verbal apology from the doctor.“This could have been a major breach of sensitive data.“I just don’t understand how they got it so wrong.“I’ve lived at my address for almost three years, so it’s not asI’ve moved in recently.“The doctor asked meI knew the person to whom the letter was addressed.“It’s horrying to think this may have landed on someone ’s doorstep.“They could have opened the letter without fully registering who it was for.“The content of the letter has information that only my closest family are aware of.“It’s a relief to know now that it wasn’t sent.A spokesman for NHS Tayside said: “Due to patient confidentiality, we are unable to comment on matters relating to inidual patients.“NHS Tayside takes the security of information very seriously and would encourage the patient to contact us by emailing the information governance team at informationgovernance.tayside@nhs.net, or by telephone on  .”

story: Celtic have been dealt another injury blow with Tom Rogic ruled out of this months Europa League tie against Valencia. story: The independence referendum was a once in a letime vote and ending austerity should be the priority instead, said Jeremy CorbynHe also said Labour is committed to the people having a vote on the Brexit deal, but that it is "a long way off".With Nicola Sturgeon stating she will set out the timing for a second referendum soon, Mr Corbyn also said that the  poll was a ldquoonce in a letime vote.Speaking in Glasgow to the Evening Times, on a second independence referendum the Labour leadersaid: ldquoIrsquom of the view that a referendum took place in  it was supposed to be a once in a letime decision.ldquoI think what Scotland needs what the rest of the UK needs is a government to invest across the whole country and end austerity and that is our priority.

title: Businesses gearing up for new adventure festival in Inverness
story: Highland Adventure Fest is expected to take place in Inverness Leisure Centre on Sunday, March .And the event is expected to feature presentations and entertainment from outdoor enthusiasts, as well as demonstrations and live music.The event is being advertised to those who have an interest in outdoor activities such as mountain biking, hiking, and kayaking among others.Festival-goers will be able to try out kit, buy new clothing and equipment, book activities and meet new people with similar interests while enjoying presentations and entertainment on the main stage.The mini festival is being planned by Inverness-based event organisers PLANIT Scotland and will be sponsored by the Glenmore Lodge in Aviemore.Katie Masheter, from PLANIT Scotland, said: ldquoWe are organising the event because the Highlands are quite often seen as a bit of an adventure playground.Miss Masheter went on to say that although they are expecting mostly local people at the event they welcome tourists to come along also, she said: ldquoVisitScotlandrsquos recent tourism conference was placing emphasis on getting the country set-up for an influx of tourists looking for adventure, so what we thought would be great is to pull together an event which brings everyone under one roof.The event is open to all.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Clachnacuddin FC pays tribute to superfan from Yorkshire
story: Bronwyn Wain , who lived in Huddersfield, was described as a ldquolovely lady and ldquoreal character by club figures.Despite living in Yorkshire, her unlikely association with the club began in  when she got in touch with the Lilywhites out of curiosity about the clubrsquos name and history.The links grew from there and she became a true Lily when she visited Grant Street as club guest in . Her husband John, who passed away a few months ago, joined her.ldquoThey were a lovely couple. Just ordinary folk who took the club to their hearts and they became well-known to many of our players, directors and fans, said Billy Corbett, a former director of the club. ldquoIt was the name Clachnacuddin that attracted her attention. Its a Gaelic word and means lsquothe stone of the tubrsquo. But when she got in touch we responded by sending her a hat and scarf and some programmes.ldquoShe was absolutely thrilled and kept in touch through Facebook checking results and encouraging the team. She sent money every month to one of our fans to buy her ticket in the Lily Lotto. She had so many friends the club had a whip round for her and her husband to visit.During the trip they attended a Clach game against Strathspey Thistle , which the Lilywhites won - ndash a result which left the couple ldquotickled pink. Former director Jim Oliver also showed them round town and on a cruise down Loch Ness.ldquoI donrsquot think they had ever been to Scotland but they got a real taste of Highland League hospitality, Mr Corbett added.Following her death the couplersquos son Michael passed on his heartfelt thanks to Clach fans and officials for all they had done for his parents.Jim Oliver said: ldquoA lovely lady whom the Clach Facebook followers got to know very well. All in all she was a real character.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: DJ marathon charity event in Inverness aims to be a money spinner
story: Several local DJs will take to the decks during the Caledonian V Cancer event this Saturday in aid of CLIC Sargent.The music starts at pm and finishes at am on Sunday, and the sound selectors will include DJs Terry Fire, Lady Beats, Andy Innis, CKaz and Richard Lewis.The event has been organised in memory of Michael Murphy who succumbed to cancer last year aged .Michaelrsquos uncle Sean , of Dalneigh, is a regular in the bar.Sean has already organised several fundraising events across Inverness, and so far he has raised more than pound for the charity.Sean said he was really grateful to the Caledonian and all the DJs for their support, adding: ldquoMichael first became unwell in  and he had two forms of leukaemia and sadly died last September.ldquoCLIC Sargent really helped us through some hard times so I became involved in the fundraising.Michael was involved in last yearrsquos Stand Up To Cancer campaign on Channel  having been filmed for the national fundraiser prior to his death.The former factory worker and McDonaldrsquos crew member lived in Forres before moving to Inverness.Mark Glendinning, general manager of the Caledonian, said: ldquoWe try to support as many local events as possible, but this one is particularly special as Sean is both a friend and regular customer.ldquoCLIC Sargent is a wonderful charity that supports cancer patients and their families during incredibly dficult times.ldquoThey were particularly helpful to Michaelrsquos we Shannon and young daughter Sophia after he passed away, so we want to help Sean raise funds for them to give something back.CLIC Sargent supports children and young people with cancer and leukaemia and the Caledonian event will be held ahead of World Cancer Day on Monday.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Game group boosts Highland Hospice coffers
story: Sixteen members and guests of the Borlum game shooting syndicate, Scaniport, managed to more than double a total raised last year, with local businesses also helping with donations in kind.The group staged a three-course bothy lunch, an extensive auction of donated goods and a series of competitions including th century musketry, a clay pigeon shoot and retriever dummy-throwing.More than  auction items donated by members and guests ranged from home-made honey and tablet to malt whiskies, artworks and several hundred kilos of firewood.Local businesses added support, including outdoor specialists Grahams, which chipped in two daysrsquo trout fishing, Highland Industrial Supplies and Allans of Gillock with tools and workwear, Harbro with a retail voucher, Tesco with food and Scissor Sisters of Dingwall with haircut vouchers. Scaniport Estate made a direct donation of pound, to bring the total raised to pound.Borlum farmer Alan Fraser, who was auctioneer for the day and whose we Yvonne and others produced the meal, said: ldquoIt was a great effort by all, an enjoyable afternoon and a huge thousand-pound increase on the pound raised last year. We all appreciate what a tremendous personal service the Highland Hospice provides for our community, and that it costs about pound a day to run, so every small event and contribution helps.Highland Hospice community fundraiser Katie Gibb added: ldquoI would like to say a huge thank you to everyone who organised and participated, as well as the businesses who supported it. To raise nearly pound is just fantastic and will be appreciated by those who rely on our care.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Highland air traffic controllers to be balloted over strike action
story: The Prospect Union has already notied Highlands and Islands Airports Ltdthat it will be asking air traffic controllers to cast a vote regarding a strike. An indicative ballot in October gained overwhelming support.The dispute centres on the controllers at Inverness and where being paid much less than their counterparts further south, which the union maintains is unfair.An innovative centralised air traffic control system that many fear could lead to job losses in years to come has also added to the bitterness in the dispute, though it is not part of the current move.Before Christmas both Prospect and HIAL agreed to an evidence-based business case that set out the pay gap between HIAL and the rest of the industry in an attempt to resolve the dispute.Prospect believesHIAL cannot attract and retain controllers through pay issues, this has and will continue to cause staff shortages and pose a risk to maintaining service provision.According to the union it has no choice but to move towards industrial action after Scottish Ministers rejected the business case earlier this week without explanation and with no additional funding offered.Prospect negotiation officer David Avery said: ldquoScottish Ministers have been promising pay restoration for public sector workers but their policy fails to deliver.ldquoThere is a global shortage of air traffic controllers which is driving wages up across the industry - at the same time HIAL staff have received below inflation pay awards.ldquoIt is unfair that a HIAL air traffic controller, providing an essential service for the Highlands and Islands, is being paid half as much their counterpart in London ndash enough is enough.ldquoOur members have tried every other means to resolve this dispute but by rejecting a fair and reasonable proposal to resolve the dispute ministers have left them with no option but to pursue strike action.HIAL HR director Andrea Sillars, said: ldquoHIAL note the position taken by the Ministers. We are disappointed that Prospect have decided to ballot their members on strike action. We remain committed to continuing constructive discussions to help resolve the dispute and are open to holding further talks with Prospect on a recruitment and retention allowance for Air Traffic Control staff. We await the outcome of the ballot.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Highland Council vows to continue dialogue after 3300 SNAP petition submitted
story: Worried parents handed in a -signature online petition to the council today in an effort to save Special Needs Action Project .Later following a meeting between council chief executive Donna Manson, council officers and Snap manager Dawn Walker and Snap board chairman Donald Robertson, the council issued a statement saying it recognises ldquothe very much valued support this organisation provides to families in Inverness.Ms Manson said: ldquoOfficers are continuing dialogue with Snap to identy other possible sources of funding to help achieve a viable position. We will be entering into early discussions with Snap and other third sector organisations regarding need, service requirements and formal processes to allocate funding. There will be a workshop in February with members of the third sector, including SNAP, to agree methods of funding and how we can redesign our processes.She added: ldquoOur discussions have been useful and I have given a clear commitment from the council that we will work with the third sector to help lever funding from where as we work together for the benefit of all Highland communities.Ms Walker said: ldquoWhile the meeting was more positive, we are still in a position of not knowing what is going to happen.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Highland MPs scathing after Prime Minister vows to reopen Brexit backstop negotiations
story: The - vote victory came after Speaker John Bercow selected seven amendments that iously sought to extend the date of departure, make a lsquono-dealrsquo impossible, place the Brexit process in the hands of parliament, and find an alternative to the Northern Ireland back-stop.All were defeated except the Brady Amendment ndash seeking a renegotiated backstop - and a non-binding motion calling for an economically damaging lsquono-dealrsquo to be ruled out.But Theresa May looks set to face a struggle reopening the Withdrawl Agreement negotiated with the EU after European Council president, Donald Tusk, immediately shot down the proposals, stating: "The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."The SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford, who is also MP for Ross, Skye and Lochaber, had earlier submitted an amendment noting how the Scottish and Welsh assemblies voted against the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, calling for an extension of article  ndash which would delay the UKrsquos EU departure - and for no deal to be removed as an option. It was defeated by  votes to .He warned that the development means Number  has brought the country closer to a no-deal Brexit and undermined the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland.ldquoBy throwing her weight behind an impossible demand from the hard Brexit wing of the Conservative Party the Prime Minister today demonstrated beyond doubt she is now prepared to take Scotland and the UK over the Brexit clf-edge.ldquoTheresa May could have worked across parties to protect jobs and living standards but she chose to side with the Brexit extremists in her own party.ldquoOnce again Scotland has been silenced, sidelined and shafted by Westminster, and we are paying a heavy price for a chaotic Tory government that Scotland did not vote for. And today the Tories ripped apart the Good Friday agreement, an international treaty the UK had signed up to."His SNP colleague Drew Hendry, who represents Inverness,Nairn,Badenoch and Strathspey, added: ldquoWith her Brexit deal in tatters after its record-breaking defeat in the House of Commons, Theresa Mays focus remains on appeasing her Tory colleagues, rather than on delivering a plan to protect jobs and the economy.ldquoShe knows this fudge on the Irish backstop cannot be delivered in any meaningful way, yet she continues to waste what valuable time is left. It is little wonder the EU  are so bemused by her behaviour.ldquoAs ever, it is the public who will pay the price for this shambles. The Prime Minister has made no attempt to recognise the views of the Scottish electorate, and the damage Brexit will cause to the Scottish economy.ldquoLabour has shown they are also not to be trusted, leaving us facing the prospect of being hauled out of the EU and made to endure all the damage that brings. It is clear Westminster is not working for Scotland and its time to take ownership of our own future.The Liberal Democrats voted in favour of the Labour MP Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment which was defeated by  votes to . It sought more to allow parliament more time to figure out how to break the deadlock.When this failed Liberal Democrat MP Jamie Stone, who represents Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross,argued for a Peoplersquos Vote because crashing out with no-deal would, he said, be a disaster for those in the far north.ldquoJobs, infrastructure, health care in my constituency all rely on EU citizens to fill vital roles and on EU funding," he explained.ldquoMPs who voted in favour of Bradyrsquos amendment were knowingly voting for a no deal Brexit. The EU had made it very clear to all involved that they would not reopen negotiations. These MPs are running after a fantasy and itrsquos British people who will pay the price.ldquoAll Theresa May has done is kick the can down the road and run the clock down even further. She is gambling with time we just donrsquot have.Mr Stone also sought to underline the importance of the non-binding Spelman amendment which stated the UK will not leave the EU without a deal.ldquoLabour MPs who sat on their hands have once again facilitated Theresa May and the European Research Groupin their pursuit of a no deal Brexit.ldquoA win for amendment ldquoI means the government has once again been told that there is no majority in the house for a no deal Brexit. The PM needs to take no deal off the table - as she should have done months ago - and recognise that people are not in favour of a hard Brexit which will damage our country.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: New bridge over the River Nairn is on track for summer
story: TEMPORARY weight restrictions on a busy rural road could be scrapped by the summer.Work to build a new crossing over the River Nairn to replace the ageing White Bridge is ldquoprogressing well and on track for completion by early summer, Highland Council has confirmed.The road bridge, which dates back to the th century and is category A listed, spans the river on the B route between Clephanton and Cawdor.It has been struggling to cope with heavy modern traffic and a weight limit of  tonnes has been in operation while a new bridge is built and the road realigned. The weight restriction has caused disruption for farmers, forestry vehicles and tour buses, which have been unable to use the existing bridge in the interim.The pound. million project is being handled by Dingwall-based RJ McLeod .Confirming that work is on track, Highland Council said that construction of the abutments for the new crossing beams was now complete and the beams were successfully hoisted into place this week.Now that the four beams are in place, contractor RJ McLeod will proceed with decking out between beams in preparation for concrete casting.Highland councillors in the Nairn and Cawdor ward, and Culloden and Ardersier wards ndash whose boundaries are spanned by the new crossing ndash have welcomed the progress being made.During the works the existing route has remained open to drivers, however all road users have been reminded about the -tonne weight restriction.Any vehicles which weigh more than this limit should use the ersion route, which goes via the A, A and B roads.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: One man campaign to safeguard cyclists
story: Allie Middletonfrom Balnakyle Road is concerned about the visibility of a cycle path which cuts through trees and merges with the east junction with Lochy Road and he is urging locals to campaign for improved awareness and traffic calming measures.ldquoI just happen to live opposite the cycle track. I would never be able to forgive myselfsomething happened and I hadnrsquot done something about it, said Mr Middleton.He is particularly concerned that many drivers do not know the cycle track is there because it is set back roughly  metres from the road, through the garden of the Green Drive Hall.Mr Middleton said when the cycle path was upgraded three years ago, a barrier was removed which had separated the path clearly from the road.There is now a sign at the end of the path before it meets the road, warning cyclists to dismount. But Mr Middleton said that the sign was being ignored and there was a danger at the bend where cyclists meet traffic.Speed reducing tables have been installed at the site, but Mr Middleton said: ldquoCars are going over the raised tables at mph and then drivers are putting the foot down in between them.He has reported his concerns to the council who carried out a survey in May last year. It revealed the average speed in the mph zone at the busiest time in the morning is .mph.He is now urging the council to instal signs to alert the drivers to the oncoming cyclists or a speed indicating devicewhich will show road users their speed.The path is used by pupils from Lochardil Primary, Inverness Royal Academy Holm Primary and the Gaelic school.Mr Middleton fears young people on the path may not be seen by fast moving vehicles: ldquoWe have crossed this road many times andin the company of two or four of my grandchildren this is more dficult, the main reason for this is in estimating the speed of accelerating vehicles since the tables were installed said Mr Middleton.A Highland Council spokeswoman said: ldquoA mph zone was recently installed in the Culduthel Lochardil area at the request of the community council. The scheme which encompasses Balnakyle Road includes appropriate signage and associated traffic calming features. Highland Council are monitoring speeds and will be making the police awarea persistent speeding problem is demonstrated. The concerns... will be investigated.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Site for Inverness homes not acceptable
story: Councillor Ken Gowans hit out at the application by agent Bracewell-Stirling for DMPM Services.He said the site was not zoned for housing and would pile pressure on local school rolls which are already well over  per cent capacity.ldquoWhile we need more affordable houses, any development must be part of the local plan, and this development is not.ldquoThis is likely to generate more unacceptable pressures on infrastructure which is already struggling to cope at the moment.ldquoWhile developers pay contributions towards education, it doesnrsquot change the fact that local schools are beyond full, and the councilrsquos school roll projections indicate these will worsen in the short to medium term, he said.Highlands MSP and road safety campaigner David Stewart also expressed some concern: ldquoI am mindful that the dual A will be at one side of this site and the rural B road will extend along another side of the site.ldquoAs it stands, this particular road has no pavement for pedestrians and this would be an issue that would cause me concern.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: aberdeen energy firm raising cash for charity with dragons glen event

title: aberdeen swimming clubs medal haul helps charity fundraising efforts
story: An Aberdeen swimming club has been splashing the cash for charity.The Aberdeen group Silver City Blues has donated £ for every medal that has been ed by a race winner at swim meets over the past four years.Hundreds of pounds have been raised so far, with  medals being ed at one championship alone, with money going to causes such as Children st and CHAS.Silver City Blues’ Mark Hadfield, who gave up one of his medals, said: “It is always great to win and take home a medal for your swim.“Knowing that donating it back can make a dference to children and their families in Aberdeen is a reward in itself.”Brian Bain, vice president of the group, said: “Some masters win so many medals they don’t feel the need to keep collecting them.“Rather than the club making a profit we decided to support some local charities.”

story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowIt#s time to celebrate the birthday of Robert Burns.In Tayvallich, Burns# best-known song will be celebrated in pioneering Scottish musician Mairi Campbell#s one-woman theatre show, Mairi Campbell: Auld Lang Syne.The show tells a very human tale through Mairi#s personal relationship with the world-renowned song, including forgetting the words when singing for President Clinton and featuring in the New Year’s Eve scene of the  movie Sex and the City. To help them know how many tatties to peel, could you please let organisers knowyou#re coming along to the event on Saturday February  and how many are in your group by contacting Ewan Halley at ewan@ehalleyMairi Campbell is a pioneering Scottish musician whose work is rooted in her personal stories and cultural concerns. It feels like home.#Christina, though, is never one to dwell too long on the past. In this book she has more than one eye on the future, asking pertinent questions about the potential for land use and communities as Scotland#s looks ahead.Having been one of the driving forces behind the creation of the #Here We Are# community enterprise at Clachan, Cairndow, she practices what she preaches. Now a store for a wealth of local memory and knowledge, Here We Are # situated beside the Tree Shop # hosts a post office and much more besides. title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayr united 2 inverness 3
story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback. Inverness were three up and on easy street after a crazy opening  minutes which saw United gt-wrap the game. But a Lawrence Shankland inspired comeback almost grabbed a share of the spoils for Ian McCalls title contenders. A relieved Robertson said: Had it finished - you wouldnt have been surprised. Somerset Park is one of these grounds that sucks you inyou give them a snf. Its a good throwback and their fans make it intimidating and a good atmosphere for teams when you lose a goal. Its brilliant...one of the best grounds in the world to come and play your football. In the past we might have lost a game like this so Im delighted.  Ayr knew a win here would take them top of the Championship and started well with Robbie Crawford missing a good chance in the first minute. But they soon hit the self destruct button as their defence went AWOL to allow Nathan Austin in for a double before Liam Polworth rammed home a third. The game looked over with barely  minutes on the clock and shellshocked Ayr took time to regroup. Coventry-bound Michael Rose rocked the post with a header before Michael Moffat drew a fingertip save from Cammy Mackay. McCall turned to the bench at half time and introduced top gun Shankland who immediately turned the tide. He set up Declan McDaid to haul Ayr back into the contest with a close range finish eight minutes after the restart. And a resurgent Ayr thought they had a penalty when Carl Tremarco appeared to handle in the box but ref Nick Walsh waved away loud protests. United continued to pour forward as the clock ticked down and Shankland set up a grandstand finish when slamming home a  yard free kick with five minutes left.  But their comeback proved too little too late as Inverness clung on. Ayr boss McCall said: Im just gutted. Weve conceded three goals and at least two of them were gted with just crazy defending. And were the team with the best defensive record in the league. I think a draw would’ve been fair but it’s just one of those nights. It’s a dficult one to take to get beat.They’re a big strong team and at times we didn’t cope with that.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr NewsAyr United FC

title: brave mcdonalds worker hailed hero
story: NewsBrave McDonalds worker hailed a hero after rescuing a gran from fireLewis Macdonald, , battled back flames and thick smoke to save the le of Nan MarshallShareByAbi Smillie:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsLewis saved the le of Nan Marshall. "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA brave McDonald’s worker has been hailed a hero after rescuing a gran from a burning home. Lewis Macdonald, , battled flames and thick smoke to save the le of granny-of-three Nan Marshall from a blaze which broke out in her living room. The sht manager was driving past -year-old Nan’s home on Castlehill Road in the early hours of New Year’s Eve when he saw flames flickering in the window. A Las Vegas neon sign – which Nan popped on for the festivities – had caught alight. Quick-thinking Lewis, along with pal Lauren Kennedy, sounded the alarm, got Nan to safety and dampened the fire with towels before the fire brigade arrived at the scene.Lewis told the Ayrshire Post : “The whole night was a blur.“We were driving back from work and I saw a fire in the window. “I was chapping on the door and ringing the doorbell. “The full house was covered in black smoke. “I couldn’t see anything. “I didn’t know how long the firemen were going to take and the house was still on fire so I thought I needed to do something. “Nan was shook up about it. “I was trying to get into the kitchen because Nan said there were towels at the washing machine. “They were pretty damp so I just threw them over it. “After we put the fire out, we sat on the wall and waited for thefiremen. They had a big extractor fan and they were trying to get all the smoke out.“It had even got upstairs, the firefighters said.” Nan was upstairs sleeping at the time unaware as to what was going on. She said: “I wondered what it was. “I could hear the doorbell and by this time the smoke alarm kicked in. “Luckily I woke and came down the stairs and there was my hero at the door. “Buthe hadn’t of been here I would’ve been a goner with the smoke alone. “Even now, anything you touch you’re covered in black soot. “I was in a state of shock. “The table caught fire and the windowsill. “I had to go to the doctor two or three days later because I kept wheezing.” Daughter Lesley Watson, , added: “It could’ve been so much worse –Lewis just caught it in time. “If that young man hadn’t been passing, she wouldn’t be here today.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr NewsAyr

title: driver who sped 70mph through
story: NewsDriver who sped at mph through streets of Troon is jailed for  monthsMark Kirkby almost killed his passenger when he finally crashed into a wall following the high speed chase.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  FEB NewsMark Kirkby was jailed for the reckless driving"Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who drove like a maniac through the streets of Troon has been jailed for  months, writes Edwin Lawrence. Mark Kirkby, , almost killed passenger Kerrie Anne Monaghan when he finally crashed into a wall. Miss Monaghan was in Ayr Sherf Court on crutches to hear the sentence on her partner, who she is standing by. The court heard Kirkby did not even have a driving licence and Sherf John Montgomery banned him from holding one for four years. Depute fiscal Lindsay Bain told the court police spotted a silver Volvo being driven erratically from Barassie Street into Portland Street. The police car’s blue lights went on and Kirkby initially slowed down before increasing speed. He was hitting mph in Templehill before heading into Harbour Road. And Kirkby’s car was said to have taken off as he drove across a mini roundabout into Port Ranald Drive. He hit mph in North Shore Road, eventually crashing into a wall at the Beach Road Kilmarnock Road junction in Barassie. During the whole episode, which began around .am on October  last year, Kirkby drove dangerously through junctions and swerved round corners.  When the crash occurred the car’s airbags were deployed but this did not prevent Ms Monaghan’s horric injuries. She had to be cut out of the car by firefighters and suffered numerous fractures to her face, head, body and limbs. “Kerrie Anne Monaghan is very lucky to be alive,” said fiscal Ms Bain. The court also heard of offences committed by Kirkbywhose address was given as Barlinnie Prison, on June . This time he was in a grey Ford Mondeo around .am when police spotted the car stationary on the A near the Pennyburn Roundabout. Kirkby was unsteady on his feet and slurring his speech, although a breath test proved negative. A a blood test found substances identied as cocaine and benzocaine. Defence lawyer Hugh Duncan said Kirkby’s relationship with Ms Monaghan was still ongoing. “He accepts full responsibility,” said the lawyer. “He comes across as remorseful to the injuries his partner suffered and to potential harm he could have done to others.” Mr Duncan said Kirkby had been remanded in custody since October , had undergone a detox programme, and had come to a realisation of his mental health issues. Sherf John Montgomery told Kirkby: “You drove dangerously at high speed for an extended period. I see no option but a custodial sentence.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnHMP BarlinnieVolvoAyrCourtsJusticeTroon

title: elliots prestwick evolve rebrand vics
story: NewsElliots in Prestwick to "evolve" with rebrand as Vics  The VineBosses at Buzzworks say the bar and restaurant must "evolve" as part of its transformation.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB NewsBuzzworks managing director, Kenny Blair, is promising bold changes at Elliots "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of Ayrshire’s biggest hospitality venues has closed for a “complete transformation”. Elliots in Prestwick will be given a new brand and feature live sport and entertainment seven days a week. The bar and restaurant shut its doors on Sunday, with bosses planning to reopen at Easter as Vic’s  The Vine. Buzzworks, who have operated Elliots as their flagship in the town, say the rebrand will be split into two halves. Managing director Kenny Blair said: “It’s essential to evolve within the hospitality industry and look at innovative ways to create new and exciting concepts for our customers. “Our work to reincarnate Elliots is part of our wider growth strategy, both benefiting the local community and Scotland’s hospitality industry.” Vic’s  The Vine will feature a -cover restaurant called The Vine serving food from breakfast until late. The bar will be called Vic’s and will be a “modern take on a traditional bar”, featuring sport and entertainment. Weekend opening hours will remain at .am.  Designer Jim Hamilton is leading the project, which will include a new glass roof in part of the bar. A new kitchen boasting a churrasco BBQ pit is also planned. Bosses say Vic’s will be the first venue in Ayrshire to serve fresh, unpasteurised tank beer straight from the brewery. Kenny added: “We’ve seen an appetite in the industry for more cool and modern pubs and, similarly to our T-Bar in Ayr, Vic’s will be a traditional bar with a twist. “This will both suit the local market and sit alongside our excellent new restaurant offering in Prestwick. “Our vision is to create the best day-to-night venue in Scotland and we are confident Vic’s  The Vine will match those expectations.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrPrestwickAyr News

title: woman 28 wielded air rifle
story: NewsWoman wielded air rle and metal pole during rammy at Ayrshire houseThe -year-old admitted shoving the barrel of the rle into the home.ShareByAbi Smillie:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsAyr Sherf Court "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA weapon wielding woman terried homeowners as she smashed windows during a violent air rle spree. Danielle Smith, , used a metal pole to shatter windows of a home on Ness Glen Road, Dalmellington on November , . But she didn’t act alone as Smith was spotted alongside a male when the pair terried their targets inside. Ayr Sherf Court heard he appeared to be carrying a black air rle. But Smith, of Castle Croft, Dalmellington, admitted shoving the barrel of the rle into the home. And the victims inside cowered in fear as they could hear Smith shouting “Get out here, get our here.” CCTV footage captured the pair on their threatening violent spree. Almost every window in the home had been smashed and holes in the windows were consistent with shots of the rle. Blood smears were spotted on the living room window. Police were called and discovered the metal pole used by Smith the following morning. A search warrant in Smith’s home uncovered pellets for an air rle in a box within her bedroom. But she told officers that the other person had been carrying the gun and she had never seen the gun before. She also stated that she threw the metal pole away as she believed the other person would have used it. Solicitor Steven Maxwell told the court he had viewed the footage. The lawyer commented: “It’s quite clear that she was quite literally in his stead and following him. “She cannot provide the court any reasonable explanation of how she managed to get herself in this situation but she was using and abusing drink and illegal substances. “At the time she would have followed this man where-ever he went. “If you fly with the crows, you get shot with them. Mr Maxwell said that Smith has “managed to turn her le around”. He added: “The young woman who appears before you is a very dferent woman. “She understands the seriousness of this.” Sherf Scott Pattison told Smith: “My first thought was to send you to jail for this shameful behaviour and very serious nature. “However I’m going to draw back from that because of your current progress in the community payback order. “I’m told by the social work department that you’re doing well. “You’re currently free from substance and alcohol misuse which is the big thing. “Butyou transgress, you’ll go straight to jail and it’ll be for a signicant period.” Smith admitted behaving in a threatening or abusive manner and, whilst acting with another, shouted, did kick and strike the door with a metal pole, point the barrel of an air rle into the home and smash windows.
