title: tranent-teenager-recovering-well-after-horror-skiing-accident
story: An air ambulance brought Nicholas Guest back from Sion on Monday, with the teenager now in Edinburghrsquos Western General Hospital.Older sister Lizzy was delighted her brother was one step closer to being able to come home.She told the Courier: ldquoHe is a lot happier for being back in Scotland. There is a big change in his presentation.ldquoWe are all glad he is back and just along the road now instead of travelling hundreds of miles.Nicholas, , of Tranentrsquos Lawson Way, was placed in a coma following an accident while skiing in the resort of Saas-Fee, near the Italian border, earlier this month.The teenager bumped his head on the ground after going over a jump and underwent surgery, with doctors monitoring his condition.On Monday evening, he arrived back in Scotland and Lizzy, who lives in Haddington, said: ldquoHe is improving little bits all the time.ldquoHe has progressed quite a lot in the last two weeks considering how severe his injuries were.ldquoHe is awake for longer and he speaks a little bit more. He still has issues with his mobility but has been referred onto eye specialists, speech and language, and physiotherapy. He struggles on focusing his eyes a bit.ldquoBeing back in Scotland has made a massive dference just in terms of his mental health.ldquoAs well as his physical health improving, we are trying to encourage him to do as much as he can and we are trying to stimulate him to the maximum and get him recovering quicker.Nicholas plays rugby for Preston Lodge RFCrsquos under-s and was visited by a group from the rugby team in the hospital.A GoFundMe page was set up by Lizzyrsquos fianceacute, Daniel Hunter, to help cover the costs of the family going to visit Nicholas in Switzerland.An initial goal of pound, was quickly surpassed, with more than pound, now collected as the community rallies round.Lizzy said: ldquoWe are pretty amazed.ldquoIrsquom shocked, to be honest obviously we changed the goal when we realised quite a lot of people had donated.ldquoWe thought maybe people would help cover the expenses and it has been incredible.ldquoThat was really helpful and Nicholas appreciates it as well.ldquoIt has been great ndash even people we donrsquot know, friends of friends, that want to help. We donrsquot even know who they are and we are just really grateful they want to help us.Nicholas, who is in S at Preston Lodge High School, Prestonpans, faces a y recovery and rehabilitation period. It remains unclear when he will be able tohome, although Lizzy said her brother wanted to be home within three months.She added: ldquoNow we are going to be focusing on being there for Nicholas.ldquoWe have got our daily lives and jobs to go to but as a family we are all within a reasonable distance.ldquoWe can co-ordinate ourselves to be there at dferent times so he has always got someone with him.Lizzy and Nicholasrsquo mum Marian added: ldquoA great thank you to all who have supported us over the last couple of weeks and those who continue to do so. Nicholas knows about the support and it has had a huge impact on his recovery and wersquore very grateful for this.ldquoI also want to express thanks to all who help and support our family.ldquoThanks to the excellent staff at the Swiss hospital, air ambulance team, and staff at the Western General.To help support Nicholas, go to gofundme support-for-nicolas

title: musselburgh-racecourse-abandons-cheltenham-trials-weekend
story: The racecourses premier jumps weekend fixture had been set to take place this Saturday and Sunday but sub-zero temperatures have put paid to the event, it was announced today.**The @bet Scottish Cheltenham Trials Weekend has been ABANDONED**Unfortunately, due to a frozen track  low temperatures this weekendrsquos Scottish Cheltenham Trials Racemeeting has been abandoned.We are looking to reschedule  more information will follow. pic alVcaiijHarriet Graham, clerk of the course, said: ldquoVery sadly we have had to abandon our Scottish Cheltenham Trials weekend because of frozen ground.ldquoWe have tried really hard to get this meeting on, putting fleeces on the whole course, but unfortunately with temperatures as low as - last night and the night before, the frost has got underneath the fleece and there is no prospect of temperatures rising enough over the next few days for us to get racing on Saturday or Sunday.ldquoIt is such a great shame as we had a very exciting weekend ahead of us, but we just canrsquot beat the weather I am afraid.Bill Farnsworth, Musselburgh Racecourse general manager, added: ldquoMusselburgh will seek the opportunity to stage an extra fixture which will meet the needs of horses that would otherwise have raced at our bet Scottish Cheltenham Trials weekend.Refunds will be made available and the racecourse will be in contact with all race-goers who have purchased advance admission tickets.For more information, visit the racecourse website and social media feeds.

title: big-backlog-of-500-street-lights-needing-fixed-in-east-lothian
story: Complaints about lights are logged on an interactive map on East Lothian Councilrsquos website, which shows that some were reported as not working as far back as October last year, with the fault still classed as ldquounveried.A senior officer at East Lothian Council confirmed the backlog as he responded to a complaint about lights being left unfixed outside a school.He said that budget cuts had ldquorun down our establishment and the council was unable to recruit enough electricians because it could not compete with private sector salaries.In an email, the senior lighting officer said: ldquoThe council currently has a backlog of some  lighting faults. We are also suffering from a shortage of staff to address the issue.ldquoBudget cuts have run down the establishment and further recruitment has proved unsuccessful, with electricians outwith local government enjoying much higher levels of remuneration than we can offer.Councillor Norman Hampshire, the council administrationrsquos spokesperson for the environment, insisted that the number of faults equated to ldquoless than three per cent of the , lights the local authority operated in the county.And he said that more than half the lights in East Lothian had been converted to LED, requiring far less maintenance.Mr Hampshire said: ldquoIn the meantime, we are continuing to inspect reported faults as quickly as possible and, where a fault is a matter for ScottishPower, we are making sure this is dealt with as soon as possible.ldquoWhere repairs are our responsibility, we have used electrical contractors to assist with repairing lighting faults and we plan to use this resource again when the need arises.Mr Hampshire added that some lights in new housing developments remained the responsibility of developers until they were transferred to the council.The senior officer was responding to a complaint about lights being left unfixed outside Dunbar Primary Schoolrsquos John Muir campus. He confirmed that the council had used contractors in the past but said: ldquoThe high costs involved mean any long-term engagement is unsustainable.Mr Hampshire added: ldquoIn relation to recruitment, East Lothian Council is experiencing the same challenges as other local authorities are as a result of UK growth and we are seeking to mitigate this impact.Among the street lights currently out of action are some at Robertson Drive and Lindores Drive in Tranent due to a faulty cable, with ScottishPower stating work is due to be carried out late next month.Check your street lights on the local authorityrsquos interactive map here.

title: retiring-golf-club-starter-recalls-meeting-neil-armstrong-and-movie-stars
story: A GOLF club starter who once welcomed the first man on the moon to the fairways has called it a day.North Berwick Golf Club bid farewell to starter Sam Fox this week, as he retired after  years of service to the club.As a starter, it was Samrsquos job to set the pace of play on the course, as well as offering his knowledge about both the coursersquos history and hints and tips on how to play it.Sam, originally from Wales, moved to Scotland as a youngster and attended Dalkeith High School he eventually joined the police, working in Musselburgh and then later in North Berwick.Retiring after  years on the force, a friend of his let him know about a vacancy at North Berwick Golf Club.ldquoI started there as a ranger, said Sam, ldquoand pretty quickly they askedI wanted to be their starter.Over his two decades at the West Links, Sam has seen many changes.ldquoThere have been  captains while Irsquove been there, and they seem to be getting younger and younger, he said.ldquoIrsquove worked through the introduction of high-tech computerised systems, elite golf equipment and the golf outfits getting more and more colourful!With North Berwick Golf Club being hailed as one of the best and oldest in the world, Sam has seen his fair share of high-profile golfers and famous celebs.ldquoThe most important customer that I had was the next one who would play ndash everyone gets treated the same, but saying that, I have met some pretty famous people, he said.ldquoI remember Neil Armstrong, the first man on the moon, coming in.ldquoI didnrsquot recognise him at first, and so asked him what he did for a living. He said he was a pilot and I asked himhe flew with Virgin, or one of the big companies. He replied that he usually flew a little higher up than that. It was only then I realised who he was!ldquoIrsquove met Michael Douglas, Sean Connery, and Irsquove recommended good local pubs to Jack Nicholson.ldquoIf someone high profile is coming round, we usually get the call a few days ahead of time. Theyrsquoll make up a name for them so we never know who it is until they arrive. Theyrsquoll say lsquoMr Brown is helicoptering in to Archerfield and will be with you at such and such a timersquo.ldquoThatrsquos when you know itrsquos somebody famous.Sam has been receiving cards and letters from people all over the world at the news of his retirement, thanking him for making their experience at North Berwick memorable.But he said: ldquoI was only doing my job. People pay a lot of money to play at the course and sometimes have booked years in advance and saved up to do so, so itrsquos important to make their time with us as special as possible. We do everything we can to accommodate.ldquoEvenwersquore having to tell people they canrsquot play, maybe because the weather is too bad or theyrsquore not experienced enough, oritrsquos a stag do who are too drunk and have fallen over trying to put the tee down, we do what we can to still make a good experience for them.As for his retirement plans, Sam said: ldquoMy we has a list of things needing doing around the house, so Irsquoll be spending a lot of time at the DIY shop I think! But Irsquove had many invites from golf courses over Scotland to play there, so itrsquoll be nice to have the time to take them up on their offer.Samrsquos we Andrea also works at North Berwick Golf Club in the accounts office and they have been married for  years.Elaine McBride, general manager of the club, said of Sam: ldquoWhat a great servant to the club, who has been synonymous with our visitor experience at North Berwick Golf Club for over two decades. Sam will be missed by staff, members and visitors alike.Sam has been praised on social media, including by Andy Bower, who said on Twitter: ldquoMyself and seven other golfers played a few years ago and before we teed off Sam spent  minutes thanking us for choosing to play North Berwick. Sent us all on our way with a smile on our face.A drinks reception for members and staff to mark Samrsquos retirement takes place at the club at pm on Monday.North Berwick Golf Club is in the process of recruiting a new starter.

title: scottish-seabird-centre-shut-for-refurbishment
story: The Seabird Centre is closed from todayuntil the start of April.The exact re-opening date will be confirmed next month after the eight-week internal refurbishment has been completed.The refurbishment is focusing on reorganising the upstairs of the centre to allow more space and a clear line of sight to the Discovery Centre.The refurbishment includes the addition of exhibits to the Discovery Centre, as well as an internal wall removed and retail and cafe space relocated.The retail area, cafe and toilets will also be redecorated.

title: plan-to-revitalise-dunbars-east-beach-revealed
story: Huge amounts of sand have been lost to the sea in recent years at Dunbarrsquos East Beach ndashwith an unsightly mix of seaweed and rock now dominating the shore.Residents have long called for action to combat the beach erosion and now plans for groynes, a breakwater and rock armour have been drawn up in a bid to reverse the trend.The proposed works, which have been formulated by East Lothian Council, include repairing or replacing an existing groyne on the south of the site that has fallen into disrepair.A rock groyne would be created at the northern end of the beach, opposite the junction with The Vennel, with a concrete groyne towards the south, while a rock breakwater would also be included.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoIt is hoped, by reducing the wave conditions at the beach combined with the refurbished groyne, the bay will retain more sediment and in the long term provide improved protection to the existing sea defence wall and regain the amenity value that has been lost in recent years.The work is split into four sections, with the refurbishment of the existing groyne acting to retain beach level in the area as it is currently.Secondly, the breakwater, in addition to providing direction protection to a limited section of the defence, will allow an assessment of capacity for a natural beach to be developed. It will also advise on any further, long-term solution to the issues at the beach.The groyne at the northern end of the beach will provide protection over part of the northern section of the seawall, with the potential to develop a higher beach in front of the wall.Finally, armour stones will be put in place along Lamer Street to protect the seawall.Discussions on how to revitalise the East Beach, which was once a popular tourist attraction, have been ongoing for more than five years.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, has been heavily involved in the talks to find a solution.She was hopeful the latest measure would help and told community councillors: ldquoThe rock breakwater, the design has been worked on for more than two years.ldquoIt is now the preferred design solution and is the subject of a planning application.ldquoThere has been a lot of chatter about the East Beach and I wanted you all to be aware of what is going on and to be able to speak with some authority.Stones weighing anywhere between three and six tonnes will be used as part of the project, with work expected to take place throughout the summer and into the autumn.Mrs Swan was expecting heavy machinery to be on the site and said: ldquoIt will require big machines, at least -tonne trucks, moving these rocks around.ldquoThe East Beach will be the site of quite a lot of activity over the summer and we are bound to get some negative comments. But, hopefully, people will recognise this is an endeavour to protect the sea wall, which has failed three times in the last year.Ward councillor Norman Hampshire was also at the meeting and was pleased to see steps being taken in a bid to revitalise the beach.He said: ldquoExperts have said this is the best option to accumulate sand in this area but nobody can give any guarantees. It is nature we are playing with and it is whether sand is brought into the area.ldquoThere has been talk about importing sand but the costs are huge and it could be washed away the next day.

title: asbo-issued-to-haddington-woman
story: Natalie Breslin was given an anti-social behaviour order , which will remain in place for two years.The Brown Street resident is prohibited from shouting, swearing, using aggressive, abusive or intimidating language or behaviour within her property or on nearby High Street.Ms Breslin is also prohibited from shouting, swearing, or using threatening, intimidating, aggressive or abusive language or behaviour at a property on the townrsquos Riverside Drive, and of behaving in a manner that would cause or be likely to cause alarm or distress to residents or visitors of the street.Ms Breslin, , is similarly prohibited from behaving in an anti-social manner within North Berwickrsquos Glenburn Road and Lochbridge Road.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoEast Lothian Council will take the appropriate legal action against those who persistently behave in a way that causes alarm and distress to others.ldquoIn this case, our Safer Communities Team worked closely with Police Scotland in collating the evidence used to inform the application to court.ldquoI would ask anyone affected by anti-social behaviour to call the councilrsquos dedicated  hours a day helpline on   .

title: strikes-imminent-at-queen-margaret-university
story: The industrial action is scheduled for next Thursday , next Mondayand next Wednesday .The strikes follow a ballot of University and College UnionScotland members in which  per cent of those who voted supported industrial action on a turnout of  per cent.Those set to strike work in academic and academic-related positions, including the library and student support.The union says the row centres on cuts that would put more than  jobs at risk.It argues that alternatives to the current plans ndash including resource sharing, management savings and extending the period of restructuring ndash have not been sufficiently explored. The local branch is considering its next steps.The university employs  staff.A spokesperson from Queen Margaret University said: ldquoWe are still actively in discussions with both unions, with meetings scheduled for next week, and are hopeful that we can make sufficient progress at these talks to avoid industrial action.ldquoAs always, we will make every effort to minimise the impact of any strike action on our studentssuch action takes place.Mary Senior, UCU Scotland official, previously said that strike action was always a ldquolast resort, adding: ldquoUCU members at Queen Margaret University have made it absolutely clear that they have no confidence in the universityrsquos plans.ldquoThe ballot result is a clear mandate for industrial action and to oppose plans for compulsory redundancies.ldquoAxing  per cent of the workforce would have a huge impact on the student experience and on the universityrsquos reputation.The QMU spokesperson earlier said: ldquoThe university has not declared compulsory redundancies, committing itself to seeking to achieve the required reductions in staff costs voluntarily, and is making good progress on achieving this.ldquoAlong with the rest of the higher education sector, QMU faces financial challenges, with grant funding falling in real terms over recent years and rising costs such as pension and National Insurance contributions.ldquoDespite a positive growth trajectory overall at QMU, with costs increasing faster than our income, we have had to take action to reset the balance and thus ensure we can continue to lead in providing relevant teaching and research.

title: pressure-on-scottish-ministers-to-release-cockenzie-site-report
story: The Scottish Government called in a planning application to build a substation on the former Cockenzie Power Station site last March after the land was bought by East Lothian Council.Now, Scottish Conservatives are demanding the findings of the investigation be made public after they were sent to Ministers in private.South of Scotland MSP Michelle Ballantyne said the decision, which came after months of public hearings and representation, ldquobeggars belief, while ward councillor Lachlan Bruce said people were left wondering what the Scottish Government was doing ldquobehind closed doors.East Lothian Labour MSP Iain Gray has already tabled a motion at the Scottish Parliament demanding a public update on the decision as offshore windfarm company Inch Cape, which put in the planning application to build the substation, begins eight weeks of ldquoinvestigative work there.And East Lothian Council has said it is also considering writing to the Scottish Government, adding: ldquoThe council believes it is important for there to be transparency in the decision-making process.The decision on the application by Inch Cape, which is owned by Chinese state-owned company Red Rock, was taken away from council planners as First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was on an official visit to China last March.Inch Capersquos plans to bring energy from an offshore windfarm onto land at Cockenzie have been criticised by the council and communities for potentially sterilising a large area of land which has the potential to bring over , jobs to the county.The Scottish Government reporter scrutinised hundreds of documents from all sides and oversaw a public hearing in Cockenzie late last year.Her findings have been passed to Scottish Minister but are not being made public at this stage.The Scottish Government said: ldquoAn independent planning reporter was appointed to consider this case, produce a report and make recommendations in order for the final decision to be taken by Scottish Ministers.ldquoThe reporter has submitted her report and recommendations on the proposal and a decision will be made in due course.A council spokesperson said: ldquoWe understand that the reporterrsquos findings are now with Scottish Ministers, who will now determine the Inch Cape planning application, and that the contents of the report will be made public when that decision is announced.ldquoThe council believes it is important for there to be transparency in the decision-making process. We are considering possible correspondence with the Scottish Government on this matter. The leader of the council has also indicated that he will be writing to express similar concern to the minister.Mr Gray said the decision on the future of the site should never have been taken away from the council in the first place. He said: ldquoIt is of such great importance to the communities affected and the whole of East Lothian that it should have been determined by East Lothian Council and local people.ldquoThe community needs to know what is happening and what the Scottish Governmentrsquos decision will be, which is why I have tabled a question in Parliament asking Ministers to provide an urgent update.Conservative councillor Mr Bruce said: ldquoThe Scottish Government denied the local authorityrsquos right to make a decision on this application in the first place, making the whole process unfair and open to proper local scrutiny.ldquoThe fact that the report still hasnrsquot been released continues to shroud this whole saga in mystery and will leave many local people wondering what the Scottish Government is doing behind closed doors.And MsBallantyne added:ldquoItrsquos incumbent on the Scottish Government to be open and transparent over their decision-making process.ldquoDuring the formation of the report, the public engaged heavily by taking part in public hearings and contributing towards the report. Local stakeholders deserve to know the outcome of the report and, quite frankly, it beggars belief that the Scottish Government have chosen to keep this secret.

title: events-held-in-memory-of-much-missed-footballer-craig-fairgrieve
story: Craig Fairgrieve was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemiain  and passed away in July last year.Now, two fundraising events are taking place to raise funds for Ward  at Edinburghrsquos Western General Hospital.The first fundraiser takes place at Dalkeith Miners Club, with a second event at Cockenzie and Port Seton Royal British Legion just over a fortnight later.Craigrsquos sister Lynsay is among those planning the event in Dalkeith on February .She said: ldquoCraig was a friend to everybody.ldquoHe was very laid back ndashhe was more laid back he would be horizontal.ldquoIf somebody tooted at him in the street he would wave and he liked a bit of banter.ldquoHe was notorious for lines out of films and he was a cheeky chappy and a guy with a smile on his face.Craig, of Prestonpans, played football for Tranent Juniors under-s after growing up in Macmerry and going to Ross High School in Tranent.He began to feel unwell towards the end of .His we Amy said: ldquoIt all started with tiredness. Craig was going to work and coming home absolutely exhausted.ldquoWe thought this was not normal and he got sent for blood tests.ldquoThat was when we discovered it was leukaemia and he started treatment at the Western General Hospital.Craig, who was just  when he passed away, underwent chemotherapy and a stem cell transplant as part of his treatment.Positively, he was told the condition was in remission and he was released from hospital, getting engaged in October .However, the leukaemia ed and Craig and Amy tied the knot in the Capitalrsquos hospital on July .Amy said: ldquoHis final wish was to get married.ldquoThe ward was really, really good and got it together. I was given a wedding dress from one of the nurses they were brilliant.A raffle and auction will be held at the first fundraiser, with prizes ranging from football tickets and golf vouchers to hair and beauty and bootcamp vouchers all up for grabs.Music will be supplied on the night by a DJ and Lynsay, , explained why the event was taking place outwith East Lothian. She said: ldquoA lot of the East Lothian venues were just too small.ldquoWe tried to keep it in East Lothian but we are looking for  tickets to be sold.ldquoThe tickets are out there and we are pretty much down to the last  or .Money raised on the night will go to the haematology wardat the hospital.Ahead of the event, more than pound, has already been raised. Meanwhile, the second fundraiser, on March , is a drag queen evening and disco.Amy said: ldquoThat is the sort of person Craig was ndash he was always up for a laugh and all about a good time.For ticketsto the fundraiser in Dalkeith, contact Kayleigh Szymanski or Dave Forsyth, and for tickets to the fundraiser in Cockenzie call Charles Brown on  .To make a donation, go to justgiving crowdfunding craig-fairgrieve

title: north-berwick-artists-exhibition-based-on-medication
story: NORTH Berwick artist Andrew Guest is displaying his medicinal artwork in his local pharmacy for a week to make a statement about peoplersquos relationship with tablets and medicine.A series of clay pots cast from the box of every piece of medication that Andrew took between  and , including everyday tablets such as paracetamol and ibuprofen, as well as the first types of tablets he took after being diagnosed with Parkinsonrsquos disease, are displayed in the window of Smithrsquos Pharmacy on High Street.The -year-old moved to North Berwick in  and, after a career as an exhibition officer putting on displays of other peoplersquos art, decided to make his own, completing courses in ceramics at Gateshead before studying pottery in Edinburgh.ldquoIrsquove always been interested in recycling and waste materials, especially pill packaging, he said.ldquoI just started making each box in clay, one for each pot, and it started there really. Itrsquos fascinating, and so much fun plasting and casting objects.ldquoI find a real beauty in the ordinary. I canrsquot paint some unique and beautul scene, but I can create something that people see everyday, and give them a chance to see it in a new light. It is also a picture of one personrsquos dependency on this method of treatment.Sheila Pearson, sales supervisor at Smithrsquos Pharmacy said: ldquoItrsquos generated some interest. People are stopping and looking and taking notice. It seems to be a positive reaction so far.The exhibition is on show at the pharmacy until Sunday.

title: sinn-fein-says-treatment-of-scottish-mps-reaffirms-belief-in-abstentionism
story: Sinn Feinrsquos seven elected MPs do not take their seats in the House of Commons, despite repeated calls to do so during key Brexit votes.On whether Sinn Fein would ever take their seats, Mary Lou McDonald told Andrew Marr on Sunday that the seven votes would be ineffectual and her party are resolute in their stance.About to go on the air with #Marr @BBCPolitics talking Brexit, borders and backstops ndash tune in #Think #Brexit https:t.co dbJSDGVZAD pic lOiLkwKgmdash Mary Lou McDonaldFebruary , ldquoI have no business in Westminster, we have no business in your parliament, she said.ldquoWestminster, correctly, advances and protects what it regards to be British interests.ldquoWe have no business interfering in that, I am Irish, we have two parliaments and we advance Irish interests.ldquoI look at the experience of our Scottish colleagues and I see them at Westminster, I think therersquos -odd, and I think they would readily attest that Westminster has no interest in Scotland either, Westminster has never served Irish interests, itrsquos not constituted to do that, Irish interests are defended in Dublin and Belfast.McDonald added that the Good Friday Agreement would have to be revisited in the event of a hard Brexit on March , and an Irish unity referendum should be held.ldquoPut simply,the border in Ireland cannot be mitigated, cannot be managed in the short term, well then you put the question democratically in the hands of the people and allow them to remove the border, she said.ldquoBear in mind the people of Northern Ireland did not consent to Brexit.ldquoThe backstop is the bottom line.ldquoOn the issue of the border poll, therersquos no point us burying our heads in the sand and wish away a hard Brexit."I look at the experience of our Scottish colleagues and I see them at Westminster, I think theres -odd, and I think they would readily attest that Westminster has no interest in Scotland either," says @MaryLouMcDonald on Marr on whether Sinn Fein would take their seats.mdash aoe-grace moore.February , ldquoWe prepare for the worst scenario and protect our national interest.Ms McDonald told Marr that anyone gambling with peace on the island of Ireland is acting recklessly.ldquoOne of the biggest symbols of success of the peace process is that people can travel unimpeded over the border.ldquoAny controls or checks or security checks, any question of British soldiers at the border ndash the taoiseach has been clear there will be no Irish soldiers on the border- no one will accept the hardening of the border on our island.ldquoThe peace process is very solid, very robust, we are only going forward and we are not going back, it would be grossly reckless and irresponsible of the Tories to play a game of chicken with that progress.ldquoPeace on this island is a precious thing, shame on anybody who would play games with that.

title: border-communities-braced-for-re-emergence-of-unapproved-roads-for-school-run
story: While many students attend schools on the opposite side of the border through schemes approved by authorities, countless others are believed to use a practice commonly referred to as ldquogrannying, to attend school in Northern Ireland.Parents living close to the border are braced for the re-emergence of ldquounapproved roads like those used during the Troubles, to take their children to school.While the UK and Irish governments have maintained that the free movement of people between the two jurisdictions will not be affected, queues of traffic affecting thousands of people are anticipatedcustoms checks are reintroduced on the border after March .A reciprocal agreement exists between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland whereby children living on one side of the border are able to access an education on the other side of the border.The caveat is that schools in Northern Ireland may only consider a child who is resident in the Republic of Ireland for admission after all resident children who have applied to the school have been considered.A practice known as ldquogrannying involves residents who move to the Republic presenting schools in Northern Ireland with proof of address at a grandmother or relativersquos house to avoid being left out.One Londonderry mother, who admits to using the unauthorised practice, has expressed concern.The woman, who has lived in Donegal for more than  years and has two children attending school in Northern Ireland, said the idea of sending her children to school in the Republic of Ireland never crossed her mind.ldquoIrsquom from Derry originally, I work and pay tax in Derry, it made sense for the children to go to school there, she said.ldquoIf there was an emergency, or they were sick and had to leave school immediately, itrsquos not practical for them to be in Donegal and Irsquom driving to work in the morning anyway so it makes sense with the school run.The Troubles saw many smaller cross-border roads become unauthorised border crossings known officially as ldquounapproved roads, which local people used to avoid customs officials and security services.ldquoIn my village alone, a tiny village, therersquos four back roads into Derry city, the mother of two added.ldquoI could confidently say % of my neighbours in this housing estate are from Derry city originally and still working there, or have children attend school there.ldquoTherersquos no way they would have the manpower to guard the border and stop every car, and therersquos no way people will wait in queues of traffic in the morning, theyrsquoll find another way to get there, theyrsquoll take back roads or roads that canrsquot be manned.Marguerite Hamilton, a former principal of Thornhill College, a girlsrsquo grammar school in the Culmore area of Derry, one mile from the Derry Donegal border, said it is ldquoinconceivable that children could be prevented or delayed from going to schoolcustoms posts were installed.Ms Hamilton said schools across Northern Ireland are aware of ldquogrannying students living over the border.ldquoWhen a child applies for school, we ask for a veriable proof of address, a bank statement or letter from a doctor for example,they can supply the proof, it is not the schoolrsquos place to go around investigatingthe child actually resides there or not, she said.ldquoAlso,circumstances change for instance,they start school living in Derry, and move even just one mile away to the south, should they be forced to leave the school and educational system they know ldquoWhatrsquos clear is that those arguing about the border in London will not have their lives affected by the consequences.Statistics on how often the practice is used are unveriable, but Ms Hamilton estimates that there are hundreds of children attending school in Northern Ireland who reside in the Republic.The Department of Education and Skills in the Republic of Ireland said it is confident the Common Travel Area will facilitate existing arrangements for cross-border pupils.Minister for education Joe McHugh said: ldquoThe school communities along the border, both in the north and in the south, have done tremendous work over the last  years in cementing the peace process and they deserve enormous credit for that.ldquoIrsquove talked about this issue in recent days with the heads of the department and the need to better understand the important role that these schools, their staff, pupils and parents have played in that and will continue to play.Likewise, the Department of Education in Northern Ireland said it is aware of the issue, but has faith that the Common Travel Area between the two jurisdictions will safeguard access to education.ldquoThe issue of the provision of  information on an application is not limited to the home address of a pupil and the department has provided guidance to schools on their duty to very application information, a spokeswoman said.ldquoA parent providing information that is found to be  may have the offer of a place for their child withdrawn.ldquoIn relation to the impact of Brexit, the British and Irish governments have agreed that the rights flowing from the Common Travel Area should be maintained.ldquoThe Common Travel Area provides citizens of the UK and Republic of Ireland with the right to access services, including education, in the other jurisdiction.

title: drop-in-labour-membership-part-of-natural-cycle-of-politics-mp-says
story: Glasgow North East MP Paul Sweeney spoke out after the Herald on Sunday reported , people have quit Scottish Labour over the last  months.Labour membership in Scotland has fallen from , in January  to , last month, according to the paper.Kirsty Blackman MP, the SNPrsquos deputy leader at Westminster, claimed it showed Labour was ldquoon the path to terminal decline and total irrelevance in Scotland.She added: ldquoNo-one will be surprised that theirtoxic support for Tory plans to drag Scotland out of the EU against our will has led to a mass exodus of party members right across the country.Labour Party sources insist the number of members it has in Scotland has almost doubled since the time of the independence referendum in .Mr Sweeney said the fall in membership was part of a ldquonatural cycle because the party had a leadership election in , which saw Richard Leonard elected as Scottish leader in November of that year, ahead of rival MSP Anas Sarwar.Mr Sweeney, speaking on BBC Onersquos Sunday Politics Scotland show, said: ldquoThatrsquos a natural cycle because last year we had a leadership election.ldquoAs many people who are familiar with party political dynamics will know, many people join parties in order to participate in leadership elections.According to the Herald on Sunday, the number of Labour members in the partyrsquos former Glasgow heartland has fallen by , in the last  months, with membership over the nine constituency branches in the city dropping from, to ,.It was also reported that in the Eastwood Constituency Labour Party branch alone, membership was down from  in January  to  last month, a reduction of %.

title: glasgow-airport-rail-link-to-be-ditched-for-rapid-shuttle-pod-to-paisley
story: A Personal Rapid Transit shuttle pod between Glasgow Airport and Paisley Gilmour Street has emerged as the likely alternative to a full tram-train rail link.Following a meeting between Glasgow and Renfrewshire council leaders, the Transport Secretary and Glasgow Airport yesterday, it has been agreed to work on a business case for the Personal Rapid Transit system.It would see passengers board the pods like ones used at Heathrow Airport to take them to the station at Paisley where they would catch existing services to Glasgow and where.AYE OR NAW, MICHAEL :Our message to transport secretary amid fresh fears over airport rail linkThe final choice will be between the tram-train option and the Personal Rapid Transit pod.It is, however, likely that the rapid transit option will be the preferred one and the option taken forward.The tram-train link hit problems following a study that said it would impact negatively on other services in the West of Scotland and on Central Station which is at capacity.The Evening Times message to the transport secretary earlier this monthSusan Aitken, leader of Glasgow City Council, said: ldquoImproved connectivity to Glasgow Airport is a key priority. However, the advice from officers and consultants is that signicant questions remain about the deliverability of the current tram-train option, particularly in relation to capacity at Central Station.ldquoAs a result, the Executive Steering Group has agreed additional work should be done to establish an alternative Outline Business Case for a Personal Rapid Transitoption.ldquoThis work was not advanced by the previous City Deal Cabinet, but it is now crucial in order to allow us to make a fully-informed choice about which of the options in front of us should be progressed.:Glasgow Airport rail link saga has dragged on for far too longldquoI remain committed to a solution that delivers improved public transport connectivity to Glasgow Airport - but I am determined it should also provide value for money for the city, and deliver the widest possible inclusive economic benefits.ldquoIrsquom confident we have made signicant progress towards that outcome today.Glasgow Airport said congestion on the M means action is needed and ldquodoing nothing is not an option.Mark Johnston, managing director at Glasgow Airport, said: ldquoWe were informed that, due to issues around rail capacity, the project partners are developing an alternative option.: Half a million to go on addressing airport rail link fearsldquoThis will be evaluated and we will, of course, work with the partners to promote the delivery of an effective solution within the agreed timescale.It has been understood that transport officials were not keen on progressing the tram-train link from Glasgow Central to the airport.Michael Matheson, Transport Secretary, said: ldquoItrsquos crucial that improving access to Glasgow Airport is balanced with the needs of the regionrsquos existing transport network.ldquoThe Personal Rapid Transit system option potentially meets this aim, and I look forward to seeing the revised business case once itrsquos completed.

title: glasgow-gateway-to-scotland-the-best-film-locations-within-90-minutes
story: Known affectionately as ldquocinema city, in the s it had more cinemas per head of population than anywhere  in the UK. These days it regularly tops box office attendance figures outside of London.It has also produced a plethora of fine directors over the years, including Alexander Mackendrick, Bill Forsyth, Lynne Ramsey and David Mackenzie.This love affair with film is a two-way thing, however, and the city has starred in many great movies over the years, spanning every budget and genre. And while it often plays itself, some of Glasgowrsquos most famous appearances on screen have been playing somewhere .Scotlandrsquos stunning scenery and history have always been a draw for filmmakers, of course, not least over the last few years, with the likes of Outlaw King and phenomenally popular TV show Outlander re-introducing the country to a younger global audience. Indeed the Scots star of Outlander, Sam Heughan, spoke recently about how much he relishes filming in his home country.ldquoScotland is undoubtedly the star of our show, the Glasgow-based actor said in a magazine interview. ldquoIrsquom so proud of the country and all is had to offer. Irsquove learnt so much about where Irsquom from and fallen in love with it even more. Each location we go to lends itself to whatever is happening in the script or the story line. We are so lucky to have this right on our doorstep.The best whisky and Burns within  minutes of GlasgowIndeed we are, and with this in mind wersquove set ourselves a fitting challenge: the best filming locations to visit within  minutes of Glasgow city centre.World War ZThe  zombie thriller, starring Brad Pitt, was partially shot in Glasgow, with the city centre getting a clever makeover to stand in for Philadelphia. George Square took a starring role in one of the most dramatic and memorable scenes in the movie, the zombie invasion, which saw hundreds of extras run screaming through the square, which was all dressed up with Philadelphian street signs and American cars for authenticity.While filming in Glasgow, architecture buff Pitt spent time visiting Charles Rennie Mackintosh buildings with his then-we Angelina Jolie and their children, including a trip to Hill House in Helensburgh. The actor is a huge fan of Glasgowrsquos most famous architect and designer, having visited the city on a number of occasions to see his work.House of MirthGlasgow was transformed into New York for this  film version of Edith Whartonrsquos  novel, which stars Gillian Anderson and Dan Ackroyd. Much of the movie was filmed in Glasgow, with city landmarks such as Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum, the City Chambers, Kelvingrove Park, Devonshire Terrace and the Theatre Royal perfectly recreating opulent early th century New York.Cloud AtlasGlasgow stood in for yet another US city in this  production: San Francisco. Both cities are known for their steep hills and location managers made good use of Montrose Street, in the Merchant City, and Douglas Street, in the west of the city centre, dressing them with period cars and signs to create a distinct s vibe. Blythswood Square also features in the film. Halle Berry filmed in the cityand was also given a s look for her role in author David Mitchells dystopian time travel tale.The Fast and the FuriousThe long, wide streets around George Square doubled for London and were used for a number of stunt sequences in the latest spin-off of the globally popular action movie franchise, called Hobbs and Shaw, which is due for release later this year. Idris Elba filmed a number of scenes - dressed in full motorbike leathers - as onlookers were treated to a plethora of fast and furious car and bike chases through the city centre.The best whisky and Burns within  minutes of GlasgowThe WeMuch of this quietly powerful movie, which stars Glenn Close - nominated for an Oscar for her role - and Jonathan Price, was filmed in Scotland. Glasgowrsquos grand Hutcheson Hall, in the Merchant City, takes on the role of Stockholm in one of the filmrsquos key scenes, while the in-flight storyline was shot aboard the Concorde that is exhibited at National Museum of Flight in East Lothian. Beautul Dumfries and Galloway also features prominently in this story of a woman who takes control of her le and re-assets her worth after her husband is awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature.OutlanderLeading man Heughan was spot on when he said Scotland was the real star of the historical time travel drama, which also stars Caitriona Balfe. The location managers have clearly scoured every inch of the country to find the best castles, harbours, mountains, lochs, hills and heather, and all of these assets are used to stunning effect throughout. Doune Castle - Castle Leoch in the show and also Winterfell in Game of Thrones ndash is just  minutes from Glasgow, while a host of other key locations, including Hopetoun House, Drummond Castle and the Fe village of Culross, are all within an hour of the city.Beautul Dunure Harbour, just  minutes from Ayr and an hour from Glasgow, featured in the last two seasons of the series. Sam Heughan, who says he spends as much of his spare as possible time cycling, hiking and climbing across Scotland, spoke evocatively last year of filming in the village of Dunure and ldquolooking across to the snow-capped peaks of Arran at sunrise.Outlaw KingGlasgow features signicantly in David Mackenziersquos brutal film about the rise to power of Robert the Bruce. Glasgow Universityrsquos gothic cloistersput in an appearance, while the main building briefly doubles as Westminster. Glasgow Cathedral can also be seen in the film, as can Linthligow Palace, birthplace of Mary Queen of Scots, just  minutes along the M.The beach scene at the end of the film, where Bruce is seen bring reunited with his we, was shot at beautul Seaclf sands in East Lothian,  minutes from Glasgow. Stunning Tantallon Castle is perched above and offers some of the most stunning views on the east coast.The best whisky and Burns within  minutes of GlasgowMary Queen of ScotsSeaclf beach also features in Josie Rourkersquos recent film, which stars Saoirse Ronan as Mary Stuart, and Scot Jack Lowden as Lord Darnley. Blackness Castle in West Lothian stands in for Holyrood Palace Edinburgh, and both royal residences are just an hourrsquos drive from Glasgow. Loch Leven Castle, the fascinating and scenic island ruin where Mary was imprisoned and escaped from in , is also just an hour away.The Da Vinci CodeRon Howardrsquos hugely popular film version of Dan Brownrsquos bestselling thriller was shot in locations across Europe, but the movie comes to a climax in Scotland, at beautul Rosslyn Chapel in Midlothian. In interviews, Brown said he always knew his bookrsquos finale would take place at Rosslyn, which he describes as ldquothe most mysterious and magical chapel on earth.The filmrsquos star, Tom Hanks, flew into Scotland in September  to shoot extensive scenes at the th century site, which is just an hourrsquos drive from Glasgow. He wrote afterwards: ldquoFew locations on a film are more delightful and few destinations live up to their billing, so to speak, but Rosslyn was all that one could imagine or hope for.The chapel, which is overflowing with strange, interesting and unexplained symbols and carvings, has been flummoxing historians and visitors alike for centuries. Due to its connections with the mysterious Knights Templar, some believe the Holy Grail is buried underneath the chapel . Whether or not that is true, it remains one of the most beautul, bizarre and evocative places in Scotland.Glasgow, Gateway to Scotland a partnership between People Make Glasgow and Glasgow Airport, in association with The Herald, aims to attract more US visitors and capitalise on a recent growth in overseas tourists by highlighting the cityrsquos position as both a must-see destination in itself, and the ideal base for accessing Scotlandrsquos landscapes, history and culture.Delta flies direct to Glasgow from JFK www.delta.United fliesdirectfrom Newark www.united.

title: snp-heavyweight-forms-polling-group-to-help-prepare-case-for-independence
story: Progress Scotland, headed by Angus Robertson, will commission polls, focus groups and research funded by subscriptions and donations.Robertson was an SNP MP for sixteen years from  before losing his Moray seat to the Conservatives.He led the SNP group in the House of Commons and was his partyrsquos depute leader for around  months. Robertson was also in charge of the SNPrsquos Holyrood election campaigns in  and .He is opening a new chapter in his le by preparing to launch Progress Scotland, which will examine public opinion in the wake of the referenda on independence and Brexit.Mark Dfley, who was the lead pollster for the UK Government in the run-up to the independence referendum, will be conducting the polling and research.Speaking ahead of the launch, Robertson said: ldquoProgress Scotland aims to help prepare the case for Scotland to progress towards independence, keeping pace with the views of the people who make their lives here. With the help and support of subscribers we will research the opinion of people in Scotland and test their appetite to emulate the most successful small countries in the world. We will provide insight and analysis on what is needed to persuade people on the case for Scotland to make progress."Dfley explained his involvement in the project:ldquoScotland has been my home for nearly  years and I have witnessed how the country has changed and continues to change. We are at a time when it has never been so important to listen to the people of Scotland and understand what the public is thinking."I am going to conduct the polls and research for lsquoProgress Scotlandrsquo and I am very excited to see what we will find. With so much going on with Brexit and the debate about Scotlandrsquos future now is the right time to ask people about their opinions, how they are changing and why. It makes sense to try and understand peoplersquos hopes and concerns especially at this time of change.However, Tory MSP Murdo Fraser queried the basis of the new organisation. ldquoYou would have thought by now that Angus Robertson would have learnt the lesson of the  general election, where he and his colleagues lost their seats to the Conservatives. The majority of Scots have no interest in independence and even less interest in a rerun.ldquoThis may be a good business opportunity for him, but I fear he is wasting his and everyone rsquos time.Ahead of the launch, Progress Scotland released a series of interviews with iniduals who are now backing independence. Chris Wilson, a politics student and young Liberal Democrat member from Lanarkshire said: ldquoLib Dems like me will have to make a choice sooner or later about which Union we prefer. I choose for Scotland to set its own path as a progressive, socially democratic society within the European Union, not as part of an increasingly right wing intolerant United Kingdom.ldquoWhile I was a lsquoNorsquo supporter in  I have changed my mind since, and I would vote lsquoYesrsquo today for Scottish independence in Europe, for the sake of my generation and the ones that will follow.Youth activist Erin Mwembo, who recently left school, said:ldquoAt the time of the independence referendum I was too young to vote, but having looked at the issues I would probably have voted lsquoNorsquo. Since then however, my views have changed and like most young people in Scotland I now support independence.ldquoBeing responsible for our own future and making better decisions closer to home is definitely the best future for Scotland and everyone who lives here. Looking at the Brexit mess at Westminster Irsquom convinced we can do better, and protect our place in Europe. I know that many people, like me, have been changing their views on independence. And I think many more will do the same.

title: mercury-plunges-as-uk-could-see-coldest-night-in-nearly-a-decade
story: The mercury had plunged to minus .Cat Braemar in the Scottish Highlands just before midnight, while most of the UK had dipped below freezing.Forecasters said there was the potential for a low of minus Cto be seen in eastern Scotland overnight following a blast of cold weather than brought severe disruption to large parts of the country.Several weather warnings have been issued for Sunday and Monday mornings, although some respite is expected with milder conditions moving in at the start of the week.Outbreaks of rain, sleet and #snow will spread east across western #Scotland on Sunday morning ndash Stay #weatheraware ## pic ebgbiFyIgmdash Met OfficeFebruary , Icy stretches will continue to be a hazard in parts of southern England and East Anglia into Sunday morning and a yellow warning is in place until am.Meanwhile there is a warning in place for snow and ice for a swathe of western Scotland reaching from Inverness in the north to the outskirts of Glasgow in the south.ldquoMuch of the UKrsquos dry, but across the north-west and west of Scotland there are some snow showers, Met Office meteorologist Greg Dewhurst said.ldquoThere is a weather warning that will be in place from am onward as that band pushes eastwards.ldquoIt will be a cold, frosty start for many and then there is the risk of some more rain, sleet and snow coming into western Scotland by the end of the night into Monday morning.

title: fai-delays-for-families-staggering-lib-dems-claim
story: Figures obtained by the Scottish Liberal Democrats following afreedom of informationrequest indicate some relatives are having to wait up to a decade following a death for a fatal accident inquiryto be completed.The Crown Office figures show there are currently  FAIs outstanding, withan incomplete inquiry into two deaths that happened eight years ago recorded as having taken the longest amount of time, at almost , days.One FAI was only completed in -, a decade after the death.A total of  FAIs were completed over the last five years, with figures indicating the averageof time to complete inquiries has gradually been decreasing.In -, the average number of days taken to complete an inquiry was . By -, this figure had been cut to an average of  days.The longest time taken to complete an inquiry was also down over that period, with , days recorded in - compared with , days in -.Scottish Liberal Democrat justice spokesman Liam McArthur said: ldquoThe sheerof these waits is staggering. Families feel powerless.ldquoWaiting up to a decade to learn the precise circumstances that surrounded a loved onersquos death is nothing short of scandalous.ldquoDelays like these will cause families unimaginable distress, hinder inquiries and prevent lessons being learned.ldquoPublic services need to know quickly what changes will keep people safe. Ultimately, delays put lives at risk.ldquoWersquove warned the Scottish Government about the hurt this is causing before. These new figures are yet more evidence that there is an entrenched pattern of delay in Fatal Accident Inquiries.ldquoIt is now incumbent on the Justice Secretary and the Lord Advocate to find the root cause of these systematic delays. Any system where it takes this long to get answers is broken.A Crown Office spokesman said: ldquoThe Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service accepts that a small number of death investigations have taken too long to conclude and has revised the way the progress of all death investigations is monitored to ensure that they are completed as efficiently as possible.ldquoWe have recently increased the resource available to the Scottish Fatalities Investigation Unit, with a view to reducing the time required to complete complex death investigations and improving the provision of information to families and next of kin.He said this represents ldquoa commitment to achieving a signicant improvement in the service.A Scottish Government spokeswoman added: ldquoInvestigations of deaths and decisions on fatal accident inquiries are matters for the Lord Advocate acting independently.ldquoThe Scottish Government is providing an additional pound million in the budget for - to allow them to continue to increase staffing in response to an increasingly complex caseload.

title: jeremy-corbyn-urges-snap-election-as-he-meets-charities-battling-austerity
story: The Labour leader met voluntary organisations and charities working to tackle poverty in the south west of the city, including food banks, toy donations appeals and credit unions.He accused the SNP of passing on Conservative cuts and said people suffering from austerity policies ldquoneed a general election now.The party highlighted statistics from the End Child Poverty coalition indicating a third of children in the area live in poverty.Le expectancy is in the area is . years for men and . for women, lower than the Scottish national averages of  and ., which figures published in December show fell for the first time in  years.Mr Corbyn pointed out food bank use in Scotland is at record levels, with statistics showing it increased by % in a year, higher than the UKrsquos %, and with the highest number of food parcels handed out to people in Glasgow at ,.Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard and Labour candidate for Glasgow South West Matt Kerr joined him on the visit.Its amazing to welcome @jeremycorbyn to Govan. Local groups like @CCG_Comunity and others have been left to pick up the pieces after almost a decade of Tory austerity. We need a new Labour Government committed to fighting hunger, poverty and inequality #ForTheMany #ByTheMany pic cAADMJwHmdash Matt KerrFebruary , Mr Corbyn said: ldquoPeople are suffering under the SNP would continue to ldquodeliver progressive policies while Labour and the Tories ldquothreaten Scotlandrsquos future and put jobs at risk.A Scottish Conservative spokesman said: ldquoAt the last general election, it was the Scottish Conservatives, not Labour, that were making huge gains across the country and winning  extra seats.ldquoVoters know that Labour are too weak to stand up to title: queen-set-to-reach-67th-anniversary-of-accession
story: Princess Elizabeth became Queen on February   on the death of her beloved father George VI.The monarch is only three years away from her Platinum Jubilee ndash  years on the throne ndash which would be a first for a British sovereign.The Government is already planning a Festival of Great Britain and Northern Ireland in  to showcase the UKrsquos strengths and coincide with the jubilee year.It is not yet known how grand celebrations for the milestone jubilee would be, falling in the year the Queen turns .But the royals were out in force for a weekend of Diamond Jubilee commemorations in  with a Thames river pageant, a Buckingham Palace picnic and pop concert, beacon lighting across the country, a carriage procession and a service of thanksgiving.The Queen will be expected to spend the th anniversary of her Accession Day on Wednesday privately at Sandringham in Norfolk, where she has been staying during her annual winter break.Gun salutes by the Kingrsquos Troop Royal Horse Artillery in Green Park and the Honourable Artillery Company at the Tower of London will be fired to mark the occasion, as is tradition.In , when the Queen thanked the nation for its kind messages after overtakingQueen Victoria to become the nationrsquos longest-reigning monarch, sheadmitted bluntly that the royal record was ldquonot one to which I have everaspired.She added: ldquoInevitably, a long le can pass by many milestones. My own is noexception.Princess Elizabeth was just  and thousands of miles from home when she became Queen.She was in Kenya on a Commonwealth tour with the Duke of Edinburgh when George VI died in his sleep at Sandringham House after suffering lung cancer.The princess and Philip had been staying at Sagana Lodge which had been given to them as a wedding present by the people of Kenya.It was .pm and Elizabeth was resting after spending the night at the Treetops Hotel in Aberdare Forest, watching big game.A message was given to Philip by his equerry and friend Mike Parker that the king was dead.It was the duke who broke the news to his we while they were alone, taking her into the garden to tell her as they walked slowly up and down the lawn.When Philip heard the news that George VI had died, he looked ashalf the world had been dropped on him, his close aide once said.ButLord Charteris, then Elizabethrsquos private secretary, remembered seeing the new Queen seated at her desk in the Lodge appearing ldquovery composed, absolute master of her fate.She was ready to fulfil the role for which she had been carefully groomed.Asked what name she wished to use as Queen, she replied simply: ldquoMy own name, of course.Lord Charteris and Mr Parker packed up, worked out timetables, sent a flood of signals, organised a plane at Entebbe, another from Mombasa to get there, and timed a London Airport arrival for pm the following day.With the kingrsquos health failing when they had left home, a Royal Standard had been stowed in the baggage.Elizabethrsquos mourning clothes, waiting for her in Entebbe, were prepared for her to wear.After a long journey home, aslim, pale figure, dressed in mourning black, descended the steps of the jet airliner at London airport.The young Queen set foot on British soil for the first time as sovereign at dusk on February .The flight was met by politicians including prime minister Winston Churchill and opposition leader Clement Attlee, as well as the Duke of Gloucester.A day later, Elizabeth II was formally proclaimed Queen at a meeting of the Accession Council in St Jamesrsquos Palace to which all members of the Privy Council were summoned.The Garter King of Arms read the first public proclamation of the monarchrsquos accession from a balcony at the palacersquos Friary Court.The Queenrsquos coronation took place  months later at Westminster Abbey in June .

title: brexit-played-inevitable-role-in-nissan-x-trail-decision-says-mp
story: According to Sky News, the company will confirm the move to cancel plans to build the new version of the SUV on Monday, just  days before Britain is scheduled to leave the EU.Unitersquos assistant general secretary for manufacturing, Steve Turner, said the ldquorumours are disturbing and many of the workforce will endure a ldquovery anxious weekend.Sunderland Central Labour MP Julie Elliott said Nissan is yet to officially announce the move, but that the ldquoinevitable role Brexit has played cannot be denied.ldquoThe constant uncertainty, the chaotic government. None of it is conducive to encouraging business investment in this country, she added.While Labour MP for Houghton and Sunderland South, Bridget Phillipson, saidthe move is confirmed it would ldquorepresent deeply troubling news for the North East economy.Tory Remainer Anna Soubry tweeted that it was ldquodficult not to be angry at the reports, adding: ldquoThis is Brexit reality.Nissan had voiced concerns about Brexit before finally committing to build the new Qashqai and X-Trail models in its North East factory in October , four months after the EU referendum.What we are hearing is that #Nissan is no longer planning on building its new X-Trail model in #Sunderland, despite whatever secret assurances it was given by the government. I will do everything I can to protect jobs at the Sunderland plant. See my full statement below: pic LNHEnlkbMgmdash Julie Elliott MPFebruary , The Japanese company refused to shed light on the situation on Saturday and remained tight lipped. A spokesman said: ldquoNissan does not comment on rumour or speculation.Mr Turner said it is ldquobeyond disappointing that Unite members heard about their futures and the holding back of planned Sunderland investments through the media and not directly from the company.ldquoThese rumours are disturbing and will cause the workforce to have a very anxious weekend even though production of the X-Trail would have necessitated additional jobs on site, he said.ldquoWe have a dedicated, world-class workforce in Sunderland, good jobs that support families and communities who deserve far better than this.He said Unite is ldquoworking hard to establish the truth behind current speculation, adding that they will be meeting the company on Monday to establish the facts.At the time, the decision to build its next-generation Qashqai and add production of the new X-Trail model at the site had eased concerns about the future of the North East factory after Brexit.Dficult not to be angry that #Nissan may pull its next production from #Sunderland given MPs like me have consistently earned leaving the EU  #singlemarket #customsunion will hit jobs. This is #BrexitReality  itrsquos why Sunderlandrsquos MPs support @peoplesvote_ukmdash Anna Soubry MPFebruary , It secured thousands of jobs in the Brexit-backing city, but prompted a volley of questions over whether a so-called ldquosweetheart deal between the car-maker and the Government had been struck to protect the manufacturer from any post-Brexit EU tarf wall.Ministers strongly denied any financial incentives were offered and Chancellor Philip Hammond said any costs arising from the assurances would be small enough to be covered within the Department for Businessrsquos existing spending limits.The Sunderland plant, which has been active since , employs almost , people, producing around , cars a day.Other Nissan models built at the site include the Qashqai, Juke, Q, Note and the zero-emission electric Leaf.Nissan is part-owned by French manufacturer Renault, which had led to concerns that production could be moved to France to avoid any tarfs which might be introduced on exports to the EUthe UK leaves the single market in a hard Brexit.According to Sky News, the firmrsquos decision is not expected to have a major impact on jobs.This isnrsquot just about Brexit, although itrsquos very clear that Brexit uncertainty is a major issue for the automotive sector across our country, and has already caused serious harm  mdash Bridget PhillipsonFebruary , The U-turn comes as figures show car production slumped by almost a tenth last year, leaving the industry on ldquored alert amid continued Brexit uncertainty.A report by the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traderssaid investment had effectively ldquostalled amid fears over the UKrsquos future trading prospects with the EU.Just over . million cars left UK factories in , a .% decline on the previous year, and the lowest for six years.Production of diesel cars was down by % to , last year.SMMT chief executive Mike Hawes said the fall in investment was ldquodeeply depressing and should send a strong signal to politicians to secure a Brexit trade deal.The reported decision by Nissan also comes just weeks after a triple jobs blow in the UK car industry.Earlier this month American car manufacturer Ford confirmed nearly  jobs would be lost at its engine manufacturing plant in Bridgend.It followed a similar move by Jaguar Land Rover to reduce its , workforce by , under plans to make pound. billion of cost savings ndash with most of the cuts in the UK.Japanese firm Honda also announced six non-production days in April under contingency plans to mitigate the risk of disruption to production at its Swindon factory after the UK leaves the EU.

title: russia-withdrawing-from-nuclear-arms-treaty-following-us-move
story: However, Mr Putin said Moscow will only deploy intermediate-range nuclear missilesWashington does so.He was speaking after the US announced on Friday that it was pulling the plug on the  Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty over alleged Russian violations.Moscow has denied any breaches and accused Washington of making  accusations in order to justy its withdrawal.Following the US notice of withdrawal from the treaty in six months, Mr Putin said that Russia will do the same.He ordered the development of new land-based intermediate-range weapons, but emphasised that Russia will not deploy them in the European part of the country or where unless the US does so.The collapse of the treaty has raised fears of a repeat of a Cold War showdown in the s, when the US and the Soviet Union both deployed intermediate-range missiles on the continent.Such weapons were seen as particularly destabilising as they only take a few minutes to reach their targets, leaving no time for decision-makers and raising the likelihood of a global nuclear conflict over a  launch warning.ldquoWe will respond quid pro quo, Mr Putin said. ldquoOur American partners have announced they were suspending their participation in the treaty and we will do the same. They have announced they will conduct research and development, and we will act accordingly.The Russian Government will procure funds and mechanisms for financing RD and design of new types of weapons in view of the US withdrawal from the INF Treaty and response steps announced by the Russian Presidentmdash Dmitry MedvedevFebruary , The US has accused Russia of developing and deploying a ground-based cruise missile that violates provisions of the pact that ban production, testing and deployment of land-based cruise and ballistic missiles with a range of  to , kilometres.Russiarsquos foreign minister said the US withdrawal from the pivotal pact has further upset strategic stability.Sergey Lavrov was speaking during a meeting with President Putin.Mr Lavrov said that Washington has ignored Russiarsquos offer to inspect a cruise missile that the US claimed violated the pact.He claimed that the US itself had violated the treaty by deploying missile interceptors in Romania that use the launchers that could hold land-based cruise missiles.The Russian minister said that another centrepiece nuclear arms pact, the New Start, which is set to expire in , is also in trouble.

title: joanna-blythman-reviews-el-cartel-in-edinburgh
story: Now I wasa fan of Edinburghrsquos original El Cartel in Thistle Street. I marvelled at the food that came out through that impossibly cramped serving place on the ground floor and envisaged a kitchen hotter than Tabasco, either behind or below, filled with world travellers who knew genuine Mexican food and were capable of serving up a respectful representation of it.Now the second El Cartel in Teviot Place, haunt of students, has left me wondering was the original El Cartel actually not as good as I remember, or is this one letting it down  A quick straw poll of those who accompanied me on El Cartel trips suggests the latter.Where the original El Cartel was electric, exciting, this one is monotonous, mundane. Itrsquos asits vivacity has been replaced by a tick box exercise, the dutul copying of the inspiring original dishes, gradually losing most of its sparkle in the process. Like Chinese Whispers, El Cartelrsquos founding message has become distorted somewhat in the telling.Guacamole, I used to think it quite special at El Cartel, is missing several tricks. Its greenness has an unpleasantly all-pervasive onion undertow, and is, by my standards, underpowered on lime, coriander and chilli. By the way, no need to order it as a dish because it turns up over and over again in other dishes, as does tedious shredded Chinese cabbage.Our pick of the daily specials, a vegetarian taco based on squash, sets the tone. The sweet vegetable is partnered with eye-wateringly vinegary pickled onions mixed with a brown salsa that might possibly have a connection with chocolate, but with bossy cinnamon in overdrive and enough chilli- and I like a lot of chilli- to ride rampantly over other flavours and reduce them to mere textures. Itrsquos one of those peppery chillis that sets up residence on the back of your tongue. I take a big slug of my rather medicinal lime Margarita and am grateful for it, even though it leaves freezer burn on my lips.Al Pastor pork ribs manage to be dull, with a lingering taste I associate with reheating. Theyrsquore in ldquocumin, garlic and pineapple glaze, a furiously fiery, fruity coating that makes us sweat and clocks in too high up the sweetness scale, but yet it canrsquot quite cover an underlying bitterness that Irsquom not actively relishing. Cashew and cabbage slaw accompanies it, but its dressing is also too sweet.We fancy a clean, refreshing ceviche, but the only fish getting this treatment is salmon, presumably farmed, which I never eat on environmental grounds. So itrsquos more meat, this time carne asado, flash-grilled flat iron steak, slicked with a salsa of grassy, slightly acidic Arbol chillis, avocado, spring onion.The tacos here are flexibly flabby, irregularly formed, hand pressed in-house daily using proper Masa Harina corn meal. Theyrsquore one of the best things about El Cartel. Duck carnitas are probably the star dish, fatty, crisp-skinned mouthfuls lightened with pineapple, brightened by hot Jalapentildeo chillis, everything calmed down by an emollient pecan salsa.On paper, this second El Cartel definitely outshines the original one. More space, an eye-catching giant mural, which looks like an Aztec wrestling an armadillo, bottles back-lit and lined up behind three stain glass windows that echo the Gothic architecture of the old medical school opposite. It takes bookings. But cramped and cobbled together as it is, I miss the original El Cartel. I leave this one sticky-fingered, with my mouth on fire. Irsquom not getting the same buzz as before, that subtlety of flavour. Itrsquos asthe impresario left before the apprentices learned all the tricks.El Cartel, - Teviot Place, Edinburgh   Food:  Decor:  Service:  Value:

title: power-plant-whats-behind-the-irresistible-rise-of-veganism
story: Power plant: what#s behind the irresistible rise of veganism The Hug and PintThese days taking the pledge means something a little dferent. Starting your day with a bowl of cardamom and peach quinoa porridge instead of a bacon roll, or ending it with a curried tofu wrap in place of mince and tatties and cheesy beans.Thatrsquos because these days ndash and in particular this time of year ndash the pledge involves abstaining from meat, fish, dairy and eggs, and buying into a movement gaining fast in popularity: Veganuary, the month in which everyone from unabashed carnivores to pescatarians, vegetarians and reducetariansare asked to try going vegan. For a whole  days. Or  mealsyou want it in terms your stomach can understand.Founded by Jane Land and Matthew Glover in , Veganuary launched in  with  pledgers and that number has at least doubled every year. Last year , people took part and to date there have been a quarter of a million participants in  countries. Pointing to a poll by IPSOS Mori about actual take-up, the organisers have also identied what they call ldquothe Veganuary Effect, which suggests that around  times that number take part without signing the pledge.The core principles turn on animal welfare and always have. As well as campaigning against killing animals and fish, vegan organisations, pressure groups and activists have long fought to shine a light on the more unsavoury practices of the dairy and egg-production industries.Those issues remain valid but increasingly veganism is becoming an attractive proposition for those concerned with other subjects, from the environment and ecological sustainability to allergies, food additives and gut microbes. Itrsquos that which in large part is accounting for the rise in veganism. Moreover, while discussions of veganism have always taken in theology, philosophy and politics therersquos now a feminist angleand pop culture is coming around, too. Alert vegans enjoying Oscar-nominated superhero blockbuster Black Panther wonrsquot have missed the line about how the Jabari tribe are vegetarian ndash but those who did because they were too busy looking at the phones probably already know that mega-influencers Ellie Goulding, Miley Cyrus and Ariana Grande, who have a cool  million Instagram followers between them, are vegan.Figures for the number of pledgers singing up to the  Veganuary campaign were announced last week and reveal that , people signed up, making it the most popular ever. Adjusted for the Veganuary Effect that means a cool two and a half million people around the world may have tried veganism for the first time last month.Kay Steven was one of them. A part-time student who lives in Edinburgh and runs a consultancy business, she took the Veganuary pledge. ldquoIt took two friends signing up to Veganuary to give me the push to do it. Irsquove been pleasantly surprised at how easy Irsquove found it and how much support Irsquove had from friends and family.For Rich Hardy, Veganuaryrsquos Head of Campaigns, that sort of testimony shows that veganism has shaken off its reputation as a sort of culinary counter-culture and gone mainstream.ldquolsquoVeganrsquo is now a word we see and hear everywhere ndash in shops and restaurants, in peoplersquos conversations on the streets, and in newspapers and magazines, he says. ldquoItrsquos not hype or a short-term trend. Any movement has to reach critical mass to succeed. We think veganism has reached that point and is firmly on its way to the mainstream.Social media and smartphones have helped spread the message, he adds. ldquoAll of us can view footage of an undercover animal rights exposeacutewe so choose. With material like that so available, itrsquos helped get more people questioning whatrsquos been hidden from them.The mainstream has certainly taken notice. Last month restaurant chain TGI Fridays launched its ldquobleeding vegan burger. Not in the best taste, perhaps, but the oozing blood came from the addition of beetroot and the rest of the burger was formed from a mixture of coconut oil, mushrooms, herbs and spices. Last week, pizza chain Papa Johnrsquos launched three new pizzas featuring Sheese, a vegan cheese manufactured by Rothesays Bute Island Foods. And even McDonalds has muscled in with a Spicy Veggie Patty and a vegan-friendly Happy Meal.Therersquos no doubting the pace of change.
